Previous studies have shown that SPRK with an intact zipper domain can self-associate and that large deletions in the zipper domain compromise the autophosphorylation activity of SPRK and abrogate its ability to activate JNK (12Böck B.C. Vacratsis P.O. Qamirani E. Gallo K.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 14231-14241Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar, 20Leung I.W. Lassam N. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 32408-32415Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar). To more carefully probe the function of the zipper domain of SPRK, a leucine residue at position 410, which is predicted to reside at a coiled coil interface (23Lupas A. Methods. Enzymol. 1996; 266: 513-525Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), was substituted with a proline residue using site-directed mutagenesis. The catalytic properties of this zipper mutant, SPRK L410P, were compared with those of wild type SPRK. Cells transiently expressing SPRK or SPRK L410P were lysed, and the SPRK proteins were immunoprecipitated and used in an in vitro kinase assay with a mixture of histones as a substrate. Data from a representative experiment are shown in Fig.1 A. Based on three independent experiments, SPRK L410P has 35% of the autophosphorylation activity and 30% of the histone phosphorylation activity of wild type SPRK. Although expression of wild type SPRK activates JNK in 293 cells, SPRK L410P fails to induce JNK activation (Fig. 1 B). These data suggest that the zipper domain of SPRK is important for its basal phosphorylation activity and for JNK activation. Leucine zipper domains commonly dimerize or form higher order oligomers. To test whether SPRK L410P in the context of its zipper domain can oligomerize, fusion proteins consisting of the monomeric MBP fromE. coli, and either the leucine zipper domain of wild type SPRK (MBP-zips) or that containing the proline mutation (MBP-zips L410P) were constructed and analyzed by size exclusion chromatography (Fig. 2 A). MBP-zips elutes as a high molecular mass complex corresponding to a molecular mass of approximately 300 kDa. However, MBP-zips L410P elutes predominantly as a single peak corresponding to a molecular mass of about 55 kDa, the expected size for the monomeric protein. These data demonstrate that the leucine zipper domain of SPRK is capable of forming multimers of MBP and that a point mutation of one leucine residue is sufficient to disrupt the oligomerization of the leucine zipper domain of SPRK. To examine whether the zipper point mutation effects association with full-length SPRK, we examined whether SPRK L410P or wild type SPRK could associate with epitope-tagged SPRK. After transient coexpression of SPRK L410P or wild type SPRK, with HA-tagged SPRK (3HA-SPRK), cellular lysates were immunoprecipitated with the HA antibody. The presence of associated untagged SPRK or SPRK L410P was assessed by Western blotting with a SPRK antibody (Fig. 2 B). The triple HA epitope adds 27 amino acids to the COOH terminus of SPRK, allowing it to be distinguished from untagged SPRK by its slower mobility on SDS-polyacrylamide gels. Although wild type SPRK associates with 3HA-SPRK, SPRK L410P cannot form a detectable complex with 3HA-SPRK. These results, coupled with the gel filtration experiments, indicate that SPRK L410P behaves as a monomer. The GTPase Cdc42 in its active form can associate with SPRK and increase its catalytic activity (11Teramoto H. Coso O.A. Miyata H. Igishi T. Miki T. Gutkind J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 14231-14241Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar). SPRK or SPRK L410P, expressed in the presence or absence of Cdc42Val-12, was immunoprecipitated from cellular lysates of transiently transfected 293 cells and subjected to an in vitro kinase assay using a mixture of histones as a substrate. After coexpression with Cdc42Val-12, the in vitro autophosphorylation and histone phosphorylation activities of SPRK L410P are the same as those of wild type SPRK coexpressed with Cdc42Val-12 (Fig.3, A, C, andD). To test the ability of the leucine zipper mutant to associate with activated Cdc42, SPRK L410P or wild type SPRK was coexpressed with FLAG-tagged Cdc42Val-12 in 293 cells. As shown in Fig.3 B, SPRK L410P coimmunoprecipitated with Cdc42Val-12, although to a lesser extent than did wild type SPRK. These data suggest that SPRK L410P can bind and be fully activated by Cdc42Val-12. Because coexpression with Cdc42Val-12renders SPRK L410P fully active in in vitro kinase assays (Fig. 3, A, C, and D), we tested whether this zipper mutant, when coexpressed with the GTPase, was competent in downstream signaling. Cells expressing SPRK or SPRK L410P, in the presence or absence of Cdc42Val-12, were lysed, and the activity of endogenous JNK was measured in an immune complexin vitro kinase assay using GST-c-Jun as a substrate. Wild type SPRK, upon overexpression, activates JNK (Fig.4, A and B,lane 2); Cdc42Val-12 expressed alone moderately activates JNK (lane 4). Coexpression of Cdc42Val-12 with SPRK further increases JNK activity (lane 5). However, SPRK L410P coexpressed with activated Cdc42 exhibits no increase in JNK activation over that of Cdc42Val-12 alone (lanes 4 and 6). Thus, SPRK L410P, when coexpressed with Cdc42Val-12, fails to activate endogenous JNK even though under these conditions it exhibits wild type phosphotransfer activity in vitro. These findings suggest a role for leucine zipper-mediated SPRK oligomerization in downstream signaling events. We recently reported that coexpression with Cdc42Val-12 induces a differential phosphorylation pattern of SPRK in vivo (12Böck B.C. Vacratsis P.O. Qamirani E. Gallo K.A. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 14231-14241Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar). To examine the effect of activated Cdc42 on the phosphorylation state of SPRK L410P in vivo, comparative two-dimensional tryptic phosphopeptide analyses of SPRK and SPRK L410P labeled in vivo, in the absence or in the presence of Cdc42Val-12, were performed. As shown in Fig.5, in the absence of Cdc42Val-12, SPRK and SPRK L410P have similar phosphopeptide patterns. Cdc42Val-12 induces a differentialin vivo phosphorylation state of both SPRK and SPRK L410P, and the phosphopeptide patterns are alike. The two new phosphopeptides observed after coexpression of Cdc42Val-12 with SPRK, and with SPRK L410P, are indicated by arrows in the lower panels of Fig. 5. These data strongly suggest that both SPRK and SPRK L410P undergo the same changes in phosphorylation upon coexpression with Cdc42Val-12. Furthermore, these changes in in vivo phosphorylation correlate with the increasedin vitro catalytic activity of both SPRK and SPRK L410P (Fig. 3). Coexpression with Cdc42Val-12 yields a fully active SPRK L410P as judged by in vitro catalytic activity (Fig. 3), yet SPRK L410P, even when coexpressed with Cdc42Val-12, fails to activate JNK (Fig. 4). To explore these disparate findings we examined whether SPRK L410P might be defective in phosphorylating an established physiological substrate, MKK4, which can directly phosphorylate and activate JNK. MKK4 was expressed in E. coli as a GST fusion and purified using a glutathione-Sepharose column. Primary data from an in vitr

The activity of the serine/threonine kinase c-Raf (Raf) is inhibited by increased intracellular cAMP. This is believed to require phosphorylation with the cAMP-dependent protein kinase (PKA), although the mechanism by which PKA inhibits Raf is controversial. We investigated the requirement for PKA phosphorylation using Raf mutants expressed in HEK293 or NIH 3T3 cells. Phosphopeptide mapping of 32P-labeled Raf (WT) or a mutant lacking a putative PKA phosphorylation site (serine to alanine, S43A) confirmed that serine 43 (Ser43) was the major cAMP (forskolin)-stimulated phosphorylation site in vivo. Interestingly, the EGF-stimulated Raf kinase activity of the S43A mutant was inhibited by forskolin equivalently to that of the WT Raf. Forskolin also inhibited the activation of an N-terminal deletion mutant Δ5–50 Raf completely lacking this phosphorylation site. Although WT Raf was phosphorylated by PKA, phosphorylation did not inhibit Raf catalytic activity in vitro, nor did forskolin treatment inhibit the activity of an N-terminally truncated Raf protein (Raf 22W) or a full-length Raf protein (Raf-CAAX) expressed in NIH 3T3 cells. In contrast, forskolin inhibited the EGF-dependent activation of a Raf isoform (B-Raf), lacking an analogous phosphorylation site to Ser43. Thus, these results demonstrate that PKA exerts its inhibitory effects independently of direct Raf phosphorylation and suggests instead that PKA prevents an event required for the EGF-dependent activation of Raf. Shapiro P.S. Ahn N.G. Adv. Cancer Res. 1998; 74: 49-139Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In the now established paradigm, peptide growth factors bind to their receptor tyrosine kinases, increasing intracellular protein tyrosine phosphorylation and stimulating the exchange of GDP for GTP in small GTP-binding proteins such as Ras (reviewed in Ref. 2Vojtek A.B. Der C.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 19925-19928Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (495) Google Scholar). Barr M. Marcus S. Polverino A. Wigler M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 6213-6217Crossref PubMed Scopus (503) Google Scholar, 4Vojtek A.B. Hollenberg S.M. Cooper J.A. Cell. 1993; 74: 205-214Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1655) Google Scholar). Lawrence J.C.J. Trends Endocrinol. 1996; 7: 43-50Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar, 20Sevetson B.R. Kong X. Lawrence J.C.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. Stork P.J. Cell. 1997; 89: 73-82Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (941) Google Scholar).Hence, the studies described herein were designed to resolve some of the remaining questions concerning Raf regulation by cAMP. Importantly, we find that deletion of the major PKA phosphorylation site (Ser43) does not impede the cAMP-dependent inhibition of Raf in vivo. Furthermore, we find no evidence for a cAMP-stimulated increase in the phosphorylation of Ser621 in vivo or a direct inhibitory effect of PKA on Raf either in vitro or on constitutively activated Raf kinases (Raf 22W, Raf-CAAX) expressed in vivo. Finally, examination of an alternative isoform (B-Raf) lacking an analogous Ser43 phosphorylation site demonstrated that forskolin prevented the EGF-dependent activation of this enzyme, consistent with PKA interrupting an event required for Raf activation rather than inhibiting Raf itself.DISCUSSIONInhibition of the MAPK cascade by cAMP and the consequential activation of PKA is a widely observed phenomenon in many different cell types (19Graves L.M. Lawrence J.C.J. Trends Endocrinol. 1996; 7: 43-50Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). However, despite this observation, the mechanism by which this occurs is poorly understood and remains controversial. Of particular interest is whether phosphorylation of Raf is required to explain the inhibition of this kinase in vivo. Previous studies have suggested that phosphorylation of Ser43 is required for Raf inhibition (22Wu J. Dent P. Jelinek T. Wolfman A. Weber M.J. Sturgill T.W. Science. 1993; 262: 1065-1069Crossref PubMed Scopus (817) Google Scholar, 49Chuang E. Barnard D. Hettich L. Zhang X.F. Avruch J. Marshall M.S. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 5318-5325Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar); however, a direct test of this hypothesis has not been performed in vivo. By examining two different mutants of Raf (S43A or Δ5–50 Raf), our studies now clearly demonstrate that deletion of this region of Raf is dispensable for normal activation by EGF or for inhibition by cAMP. This is consistent with studies showing that the primary Ras binding domain of Raf includes amino acids 51–131 (see Ref. 12Morrison D.K. Cutler R.E. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1997; 9: 174-179Crossref PubMed Scopus (534) Google Scholar and references therein) and would imply that Ser43 is outside the region required for Raf/Ras binding in vivo. These conclusions are further supported by our findings with B-Raf showing that cAMP inhibits activation of a related isoform lacking an analogous Ser43phosphorylation site. Although our phosphopeptide mapping results confirm that Ser43 is the major site of cAMP-stimulated phosphorylation in c-Raf in vivo (26Morrison D.K. Heidecker G. Rapp U.R. Copeland T.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 17309-17316Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), the finding that removing Ser43 does not affect Raf regulation indicates that phosphorylation of this site remains an enigma.Previously it was suggested that phosphorylation of Raf on Ser621 was responsible for inhibition of c-Raf kinasein vivo (28Mischak H. Seitz T. Janosch P. Eulitz M. Steen H. Schellerer M. Philipp A. Kolch W. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 5409-5418Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar). Although the authors demonstrated that PKA phosphorylated Raf on Ser621 in vitro, evidence for the forskolin or cAMP-stimulated phosphorylation of Ser621 in vivo was not presented. In our phosphopeptide mapping studies, we observed two constitutively phosphorylated peptides in Raf, one of which co-migrated with the synthetic Ser621 tryptic peptide, whereas the other most likely corresponds to the Ser259 autophosphorylation peptide as shown earlier (26Morrison D.K. Heidecker G. Rapp U.R. Copeland T.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 17309-17316Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We found no evidence for increased phosphorylation of Ser621 in response to forskolin treatment of cells. Instead, this peptide was phosphorylated equally in both untreated and forskolin-treated cells, consistent with this amino acid being a major autophosphorylation site in vivo (26Morrison D.K. Heidecker G. Rapp U.R. Copeland T.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 17309-17316Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and arguing against Ser621 as a valid PKA phosphorylation sitein vivo. In addition, compared with the Ser43peptide, the Ser621 peptide lacks the optimal pair of basic residues (RSAS) and is a poor substrate for PKAin vitro. Phosphorylation of the Ser621 peptide occurred at a rate approximately 100 times lower than that observed with the Ser43 peptide in vitro. 2M. Sidovar, unpublished observations. Instead, Ser621 is efficiently phosphorylated by the AMP-activated protein kinase (50Sprenkle A.B. Davies S.P. Carling D. Hardie D.G. Sturgill T.W. FEBS Lett. 1997; 403: 254-258Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). In other studies, phosphorylation of Ser621 has been shown to be required for both 14-3-3 binding and Raf activity (5Thorson J.A., Yu, L.W. Hsu A.L. Shih N.Y. Graves P.R. Tanner J.W. Allen P.M. Piwnica-Worms H. Shaw A.S. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 5229-5238Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). Hence, it seems unlikely that a phosphorylation site that is essential for Raf activity would also be required for inhibition as suggested by Kolch and co-workers (28Mischak H. Seitz T. Janosch P. Eulitz M. Steen H. Schellerer M. Philipp A. Kolch W. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 5409-5418Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar). These observations combined with our in vivo phosphopeptide mapping studies strongly suggest that phosphorylation of Ser621 does not mediate the cAMP-dependent inhibition of Raf kinase in vivo.Although our data demonstrated that phosphorylation of Ser43 was not required for the inhibition of Raf kinasein vivo, PKA might still prevent Raf/Ras association at the plasma membrane as suggested earlier (22Wu J. Dent P. Jelinek T. Wolfman A. Weber M.J. Sturgill T.W. Science. 1993; 262: 1065-1069Crossref PubMed Scopus (817) Google Scholar). Our experiments with Raf-CAAX were designed to test this hypothesis, and, consistent with this model, we find that this protein is completely resistant to inhibition by cAMP. Although these results may argue that the primary effect of PKA is to disrupt Ras/Raf association, there are other potential interpretations of these results. For instance, once activated, Raf may be resistant to the effects of PKA. Our results with the PKA phosphorylation of active Raf in vitro or forskolin treatment of the Raf 22W cells would support this model. Using either the baculovirus-expressed Raf, the EGF-activated WT, or S43A Raf from HEK cells, the truncated and active form of Raf expressed in NIH 3T3 cells or Raf-CAAX, we found no evidence for the direct inhibition of Raf kinase by PKA either in vitro or in vivo. In this regard, our results are in agreement with the studies of Whitehurst et al. (51Whitehurst C.E. Owaki H. Bruder J.T. Rapp U.R. Geppert T.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 5594-5599Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar), suggesting that the catalytic subunit of c-Raf is not directly inhibited by PKA.Instead, our findings would be consistent with cAMP inhibiting an event required for the activation of both B- and c-Raf. This hypothesis would be in agreement with earlier studies showing that cAMP inhibited the Ras-dependent activation of B-Raf (29Vaillancourt R.R. Gardner A.M. Johnson G.L. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 6522-6530Crossref PubMed Scopus (146) Google Scholar, 30Peraldi P. Frodin M. Barnier J.V. Calleja V. Scimeca J.C. Filloux C. Calothy G. Van Obberghen E. FEBS Lett. 1995; 357: 290-296Crossref PubMed Scopus (75) Google Scholar) and would be supported by our results demonstrating that forskolin prevents the EGF-dependent activation of both B- and c-Raf in GN4 cells. The lack of effect of forskolin on the basal activity of either B- or c-Raf in GN4 cells reiterates our findings showing that PKA does not directly inhibit the catalytic activity of Raf. Because the catalytic regions of both B-Raf and c-Raf are highly homologous (35Sithanandam G. Kolch W. Duh F.M. Rapp U.R. Oncogene. 1990; 5: 1775-1780PubMed Google Scholar) and because other recent studies have found that B-Raf is resistant to inhibition by PKA (32MacNicol M.C. MacNicol A.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 13193-13197Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar), we believe argues against a direct effect of PKA on the catalytic domain of Raf. Although these authors (32MacNicol M.C. MacNicol A.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 13193-13197Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar) did see a partial inhibitory effect of PKA on c-Raf (less than 50%), we do not believe that this incomplete effect accounts for the greater than 90% inhibition of c-Raf activity that we observed in vivo.Additional targets that were not investigated in this study include the Rap proteins. Although these proteins are phosphorylated by PKAin vivo (37Siess W. Winegar D.A. Lapetina E.G. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1990; 170: 944-950Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar) and can physically antagonize the binding of c-Raf to Ras (52Zhang X.F. Settleman J. Kyriakis J.M. Takeuchi-Suzuki E. Elledge S.J. Marshall M.S. Bruder J.T. Rapp U.R. Avruch J. Nature. 1993; 364: 308-313Crossref PubMed Scopus (684) Google Scholar), the most recent studies suggest that PKA phosphorylation may diminish the inhibitory potential of these proteins (53Hu C.D. Kariya K. Okada T. Qi X. Song C. Kataoka T. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 48-51Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar). Gelsolin is activated by Ca2+to sever actin filaments. Ca2+ regulation is conferred on the N-terminal half by the C-terminal half. This paper seeks to understand how Ca2+ regulates gelsolin by testing the “tail helix latch hypothesis,” which is based on the structural data showing that gelsolin has a C-terminal tail helix that contacts the N-terminal half in the absence of Ca2+. Ca2+ activation of gelsolin at 37 °C occurs in three steps, with apparent K d for Ca2+ of 0.1, 0.3, and 6.4 × 10−6m. Tail helix truncation decreases the apparent Ca2+ requirement for severing to 10−7m and eliminates the conformational change observed at 10−6mCa2+. The large decrease in Ca2+ requirement for severing is not due to a change in Ca2+ binding nor to Ca2+-independent activation of the C-terminal halfper se. Thus, the tail helix latch is primarily responsible for transmitting micromolar Ca2+ information from the gelsolin C-terminal half to the N-terminal half. Occupation of submicromolar Ca2+-binding sites primes gelsolin for severing, but gelsolin cannot sever because the tail latch is still engaged. Unlatching the tail helix by 10−6mCa2+ releases the final constraint to initiate the severing cascade. Gelsolin is activated by Ca2+to sever actin filaments. Ca2+ regulation is conferred on the N-terminal half by the C-terminal half. This paper seeks to understand how Ca2+ regulates gelsolin by testing the “tail helix latch hypothesis,” which is based on the structural data showing that gelsolin has a C-terminal tail helix that contacts the N-terminal half in the absence of Ca2+. Ca2+ activation of gelsolin at 37 °C occurs in three steps, with apparent K d for Ca2+ of 0.1, 0.3, and 6.4 × 10−6m. Tail helix truncation decreases the apparent Ca2+ requirement for severing to 10−7m and eliminates the conformational change observed at 10−6mCa2+. The large decrease in Ca2+ requirement for severing is not due to a change in Ca2+ binding nor to Ca2+-independent activation of the C-terminal halfper se. Thus, the tail helix latch is primarily responsible for transmitting micromolar Ca2+ information from the gelsolin C-terminal half to the N-terminal half. Occupation of submicromolar Ca2+-binding sites primes gelsolin for severing, but gelsolin cannot sever because the tail latch is still engaged. Unlatching the tail helix by 10−6mCa2+ releases the final constraint to initiate the severing cascade. N-terminal C-terminal half segment(s) Gelsolin is a Ca2+-regulated actin filament severing and capping protein (reviewed in Refs. 1Sun H.-Q. Lin K.-M. Yamamoto M. Yin H.L Gordon S. Phagocytosis and Pathogens. 5. JAI Press Inc., Greenwich1998: 319-340Google Scholar and 2Sun H.-Q. Yamamoto M. Mejillano M. Yin H.L J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 33179-33182Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (475) Google Scholar) that is implicated in actin remodeling during agonist signaling and apoptosis. It is activated by Ca2+ and/or by caspase-3 cleavage to release the Ca2+-insensitive N-terminal half (N-half)1 (3Kothakota S. Azuma T. Reinhard C. Klippel A. Tang J. Chu K. McGarry T.J. Kirschner M.W. Koths K. Kwiatkowski D.J. Williams L.T Science. 1997; 278: 294-298Crossref PubMed Scopus (1037) Google Scholar). The involvement of gelsolin in cytoskeletal destruction during apoptosis highlights the importance of clamping it in the inactive state and regulating its activity stringently to achieve controlled severing in nonapoptotic cells. This paper seeks to understand how gelsolin is prevented from severing actin filaments and how it is activated by Ca2+. Gelsolin has six homologous domains (segments (S) 1–6) which are separated into the N-half (S1–3) and the C-terminal (C)-half (S4–6) by a long linker (4Kwiatkowski D.P. Stossel T.P. Orkin S.H. Mole J.E. Colten H.R. Yin H.L Nature. 1986; 323: 455-458Crossref PubMed Scopus (370) Google Scholar). The N-half severs actin filaments (5Chaponnier C. Janmey P.A. Yin H.L J. Cell Biol. 1986; 103: 1473-1481Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar, 6Bryan J. Hwo S J. Cell Biol. 1986; 102: 1439-1446Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar) by binding along the sides of actin filament through an S2 site (7Yin H.L. Iida K. Janmey P.A J. Cell Biol. 1988; 106: 805-812Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar, 8Bryan J J. Cell Biol. 1988; 106: 1553-1562Crossref PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar) and positioning S1 to intercalate between two adjacent actin protomers within one strand of the filament (9McLaughlin P.J. Gooch J.T. Mannherz H.-G. Weeds A.G. A Nature. 1993; 364: 685-692Crossref PubMed Scopus (495) Google Scholar). The N-half severs in exceedingly low Ca2+, whereas the C-half binding to actin requires 10−6m Ca2+ (5Chaponnier C. Janmey P.A. Yin H.L J. Cell Biol. 1986; 103: 1473-1481Crossref PubMed Scopus (122) Google Scholar, 8Bryan J J. Cell Biol. 1988; 106: 1553-1562Crossref PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar). Biochemical and biophysical studies suggest that Ca2+ opens up gelsolin by inducing a conformational change in the C-half (10Kwiatkowski D. Janmey P.A. Yin H.L J. Cell Biol. 1989; 108: 1717-1726Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar, 11Patkowski A. Seils J. Hinssen H. Dorfmuller TH Biopolymers. 1990; 30: 427-435Crossref Scopus (25) Google Scholar) to expose actin-binding sites on the N-half. Thus, the C-half acts as a regulatory domain to impose Ca2+ regulation on the N-half. Remarkably, deletion of just 23 residues (Phe733–Ala755) (see Fig.1 A) from the C terminus allows gelsolin to sever in the absence of Ca2+ (in EGTA) (10Kwiatkowski D. Janmey P.A. Yin H.L J. Cell Biol. 1989; 108: 1717-1726Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar). These results provide the first indication that the gelsolin C terminus has a major role in transmitting Ca2+ regulation from the C-half to the N-half. The three-dimensional crystal structure of gelsolin in the absence of Ca2+ (i.e. in EGTA) (12Burtnick L.D. Koepf E.K. Grimes J. Jones E.Y. Stuart D.I. McLaughlin P.J. Robinson R.C Cell. 1997; 90: 661-670Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar) shows that these residues are part of the S6 tail (Phe732–Ala755). The tail contains a proximal unstructured strand (which will be referred to as the tail loop) that is capped at the C terminus by a short helix (Pro744–Ala754). The S6 tail helix is closely aligned with the S2 actin-binding helix (12Burtnick L.D. Koepf E.K. Grimes J. Jones E.Y. Stuart D.I. McLaughlin P.J. Robinson R.C Cell. 1997; 90: 661-670Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar). Therefore, the tail helix may act as a latch to block S2 from binding to actin. We will refer to this potential mode of regulation as the “tail helix latch” mechanism. The importance of S6 in maintaining the inactive gelsolin conformation is further supported by the finding that isolated S1 associates with S2–6 but not with S2–5 in EGTA (13Pope B.J. Gooch J.T. Weeds A.G Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 15848-15855Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). S6 therefore appears to be important in maintaining S1 association with the rest of the molecule in EGTA, and Ca2+ destabilizes this association. However, because S6 makes multiple contacts with the N-half in addition to latching onto the S2 helix (12Burtnick L.D. Koepf E.K. Grimes J. Jones E.Y. Stuart D.I. McLaughlin P.J. Robinson R.C Cell. 1997; 90: 661-670Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar), the role of the tail helix latch on Ca2+ regulation is not established conclusively. In addition, although there is general agreement that gelsolin is activated by Ca2+, how much Ca2+ is required is still disputed. Initial studies show that cytoplasmic and naturally occurring plasma gelsolin bind two Ca2+ with 10−6m K d and is activated by 10−6m Ca2+ to sever actin filaments (14Yin H.L. Hartwig J.H. Maruyama K. Stossel T.P J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 9693-9697Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Weeds A.G. Gooch J. Pope B. Harris H.E Eur. J. Biochem. 1986; 161: 69-76Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar, 16Bryan J. Kurth M.C J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 7480-7487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Subsequent studies find that gelsolin interactions with Ca2+ may be more complex than initially anticipated. Isolated recombinant plasma gelsolin domains have at least three Ca2+-binding sites, two with K d of 0.2 × 10−6m and one withK d of 2 × 10−6m (17Way M. Gooch J. Pope B. Weeds A.G J. Cell Biol. 1989; 109: 593-605Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar,18Pope B. Maciver S. Weeds A Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 1583-1588Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). Binding to actin generates additional intermolecular and intramolecular sites (9McLaughlin P.J. Gooch J.T. Mannherz H.-G. Weeds A.G. A Nature. 1993; 364: 685-692Crossref PubMed Scopus (495) Google Scholar, 16Bryan J. Kurth M.C J. Biol. Chem. 1984; 259: 7480-7487Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 19Robinson R.C. Mejillano M. Le V. Burtnick L.D. Yin H.L. Choe S. Science. 1999; 286: 1939-1942Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). It is not known which of these Ca2+-binding sites are functionally significant. Unexpectedly, although gelsolin undergoes a conformational change at submicromolar Ca2+ (13Pope B.J. Gooch J.T. Weeds A.G Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 15848-15855Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 20Kinosian H.J. Newman J. Lincoln B. Selden L.A. Gershman L.C. Estes J.E Biophy. J. 1998; 75: 3092-3100Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar), severing by gelsolin requires 10−5m Ca2+ at room temperature (20Kinosian H.J. Newman J. Lincoln B. Selden L.A. Gershman L.C. Estes J.E Biophy. J. 1998; 75: 3092-3100Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar, 21Lamb J.A. Allen P.G. Tuan B.Y. Janmey P.A J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 8999-9004Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Recently, it has been suggested that the high apparent requirement for severing is artifactual because the rate of severing is slow, and most severing assays are not carried out at equilibrium (20Kinosian H.J. Newman J. Lincoln B. Selden L.A. Gershman L.C. Estes J.E Biophy. J. 1998; 75: 3092-3100Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar,22Allen P.G. Janmey P.A J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 32916-32923Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In this paper, we tested the tail helix latch hypothesis and examined the structural basis and physiological relevance of Ca2+regulation of gelsolin. We found that Ca2+ induces structural rearrangements that are reflected in a three-step change in the intrinsic tryptophan fluorescence of gelsolin. A major component of these changes occurs at 10−6mCa2+ when the gelsolin S6 distal tail helix is unlatched from the gelsolin N-half. In addition, we uncovered a role for another part of the S6 tail, the proximal tail loop, in the Ca2+regulation of the gelsolin C-half. This study provides the first biochemical support for the tail latch hypothesis (12Burtnick L.D. Koepf E.K. Grimes J. Jones E.Y. Stuart D.I. McLaughlin P.J. Robinson R.C Cell. 1997; 90: 661-670Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar) and identifies an additional component in the tail that regulates gelsolin. The six segments of human plasma gelsolin were previously defined by proteolytic cleavage (4Kwiatkowski D.P. Stossel T.P. Orkin S.H. Mole J.E. Colten H.R. Yin H.L Nature. 1986; 323: 455-458Crossref PubMed Scopus (370) Google Scholar). These demarcations are now refined based on the gelsolin crystal structure (12Burtnick L.D. Koepf E.K. Grimes J. Jones E.Y. Stuart D.I. McLaughlin P.J. Robinson R.C Cell. 1997; 90: 661-670Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar). They are S1, Pro39–Tyr133; S2, Gly137–Gly248; S3, Ala271–Gln364; S4, Gln419–Leu511; S5, Pro516–Leu618; and S6, Pro640–Gly731. The expression vector for full-length human plasma gelsolin (GS755) has been described previously (23Lin K.-M. Wenegieme E.F. Lu P.-J. Chen C.-S. Yin H.L J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 20443-20450Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). The tail deleted constructs GS744, GS738, and GS732 were generated by using polymerase chain reaction to create fragments starting from gelsolin coding sequence nucleotide 1522 and ending with a termination codon in tandem with a HindIII site at the desired 3′ position of the gelsolin cDNA. The polymerase chain reaction products were cloned into pGEMT-easy vector (Promega). The constructs were digested with SmaI (gelsolin coding nucleotide 1648) and HindIII. These fragments were used to replace the wild type SmaI-HindIII cassette in full-length gelsolin in pet21a. The C-terminal half expression vector (encompassing gelsolin residues 407–755) was described in Lin et al. (23Lin K.-M. Wenegieme E.F. Lu P.-J. Chen C.-S. Yin H.L J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 20443-20450Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). C-terminal truncations were generated by polymerase chain reaction and subcloned in pet21a. All constructs were sequenced and found to have no artifactual mutations. Recombinant proteins were expressed in bacteria, lysed in 1 mm dithiothreitol and 5 mm EGTA, and purified by sequential anion and cation exchange chromatography (24Yu F.-X. Zhou D. Yin H.L J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 19269-19275Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Proteins were dialyzed against 25 mm Hepes, pH 7.0, 80 mm KCl and 1 mm EGTA and stored at −70 °C in small aliquots. Protein concentration was determined by the method of Bradford (25Bradford M.M Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref Scopus (215632) Google Scholar). Koepf E.K. Grimes J. Jones E.Y. Stuart D.I. McLaughlin P.J. Robinson R.C Cell. 1997; 90: 661-670Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar, 13Pope B.J. Gooch J.T. Weeds A.G Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 15848-15855Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 26Wen D. Corina K. Chow E.P. Miller S. Janmey P.A. Pepinsky R.B Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 9700-9709Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar, 27Allen P.G FEBS Lett. 1997; 401: 89-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). It was oxidized by incubation with 2 mm oxidized glutathione (Sigma) at 24 °C in 25 mm Hepes, pH 7.0, 80 mm KCl, and 1 mm EGTA for 20 min (26Wen D. Corina K. Chow E.P. Miller S. Janmey P.A. Pepinsky R.B Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 9700-9709Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Pepinsky R.B Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 9700-9709Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Severing was measured by following the decrease in pyrene actin fluorescence as filaments (F-actin) depolymerize after dilution (10Kwiatkowski D. Janmey P.A. Yin H.L J. Cell Biol. 1989; 108: 1717-1726Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar). Rabbit muscle actin labeled withN-(1-pyrenyl)iodoacetamide (Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR) was mixed with unlabeled actin at a 1:2 molar ratio and polymerized overnight at 4.8 × 10−6m(unlabeled actin) in buffer B (25 mm Hepes, pH 7.2, 150 mm KCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 0.5 mm ATP, 0.2 mm CaCl2, and 0.5 mm β-mercaptoethanol). F-actin was diluted to 1.6 × 10−7m with buffer B containing 0.4 mm EGTA/CaCl2 and gelsolin. The sample was vortexed gently, and recording was started immediately after mixing. The change in fluorescence intensity was monitored in a Perkin-Elmer LS-5 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The difference in the slope of the fluorescence curves with and without gelsolin is defined as the rate of severing and is expressed as a percentage of that observed at 8.7 × 10−5m Ca2+. Free Ca2+ concentrations were estimated using a computer program (28Fabiato A J. Physiol. 1979; 75: 463-505PubMed Google Scholar, 29Fabiato A J. Gen. Physiol. 1981; 78: 457-497Crossref PubMed Scopus (383) Google Scholar) and actual free Ca2+ concentrations were measured with Ca2+-sensitive dyes (fluo3 (K d , 390 nm) or calcium green [K d 14 μm]) (23Lin K.-M. Wenegieme E.F. Lu P.-J. Chen C.-S. Yin H.L J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 20443-20450Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). There is reasonable agreement between calculated and actual free Ca2+ up to 5 × 10−6m. The computer program overestimates free Ca2+ at higher calcium concentration. The gelsolin C-half binds actin monomers to prevent polymerization (30Kwiatkowski D. Janmey P.A. Mole J. Yin H.L J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 15232-15238Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This is reflected in an increase in the critical concentration for actin polymerization (C c). Pyrene actin (ranging from 0.2 to 6 × 10−7m) was polymerized in buffer B in the presence of 6 × 10−7m gelsolin C-half for 16 h. Pyrene-actin fluorescence intensity measured at 24 °C was plotted against the total actin concentration (30Kwiatkowski D. Janmey P.A. Mole J. Yin H.L J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 15232-15238Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), andC c was derived from the xintercept. Fluorescence spectra of gelsolin were recorded at 37 °C with a QM-1 fluorometer (Photon Technology International) as described in Ref. 23Lin K.-M. Wenegieme E.F. Lu P.-J. Chen C.-S. Yin H.L J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 20443-20450Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar. Gelsolin in 24 mm Hepes, pH 7.2, 100 mm KCl, 0.4 mm EGTA was equilibrated with stirring for 3 h in the dark and was transferred to a 1-cm2 quartz cuvette. The sample was excited at 292 nm. CaCl2 (100 or 25 mm) was added in 1-μl increments, and fluorescence was recorded after 5 min of stirring. The decrease in fluorescence emission at 320 nm was expressed as the difference betweenF max and F. F is the fluorescence quenching at a given Ca2+ concentration, andF max is the maximum quenching. The latter value is obtained by extrapolation from the hyperbolic quenching curve using the Hyperbol.fit program in SigmaPlot. F maxcannot be directly measured because the gelsolin sample was diluted by sequential addition of Ca2+ solution.(F max − F) was plotted against measured free Ca2+ concentrations. Plasmin and chymotrypsin were purchased from Sigma. Stock solutions containing 100 μg/ml enzyme were prepared and added to gelsolin in 25 mm Hepes, pH 7.2, 150 mm KCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EGTA and a range of Ca2+ concentrations at 37 °C. Digestion was stopped by boiling in SDS gel sample buffer. Polypeptides were separated by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and detected by Coomassie Blue staining. They were mapped by Western blotting with epitope-specific antibodies, and in some cases, by N-terminal amino acid sequencing. Ca2+binding was determined using the Centrifree micropartition system (Amicon). Proteins were dialyzed for 48 h against 25 mm Hepes, pH 7.0, 80 mm KCl prepared in Ca2+-free water. 150 μl of 1.0 × 10−5m gelsolin or GS744 was incubated for 10 min at room temperature with 45CaCl2 (NEN Life Science Products) in Centrifree microconcentrators. The CaCl2concentration ranged from 0.025 to 6 × 10−5m and has a specific activity of 1.14–1.5 × 104 cpm/nmol. The microconcentrators were centrifuged in a fixed angle rotor at 1000 × g for 1 min.45Ca in 10-μl aliquots of the retentate and the ultrafiltrate was determined by scintillation counting. Values for bound Ca2+ were obtained by subtracting free Ca2+ in the ultrafiltrate from that in the retentate. Sci. 1949; 51: 660-672Crossref Scopus (17798) Google Scholar) and analyzed by linear regression using SigmaPlot. There is considerable disagreement as to how much Ca2+ is required to activate gelsolin. Conflicting results may be due to different methods used to measure gelsolin function, the existence of disulfide and non-disulfide-bonded gelsolins (26Wen D. Corina K. Chow E.P. Miller S. Janmey P.A. Pepinsky R.B Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 9700-9709Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar, 27Allen P.G FEBS Lett. 1997; 401: 89-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar), and the effect of pH on Ca2+ sensitivity (21Lamb J.A. Allen P.G. Tuan B.Y. Janmey P.A J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 8999-9004Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 23Lin K.-M. Wenegieme E.F. Lu P.-J. Chen C.-S. Yin H.L J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 20443-20450Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). We therefore decided to characterize severing with recombinant gelsolin that is not disulfide-bonded and therefore equivalent to cytoplasmic gelsolin. Severing was assayed at 37 °C instead of at room temperature used in most previous studies. The pyrene-actin depolymerizing assay shows that at 37 °C, gelsolin severing is detectable at 5 × 10−7m, becomes half-maximal at 2.2 × 10−6m and continues to increase up to 10−4m (Fig.1 B). The Ca2+concentration at which half-maximal severing is observed is defined as the apparent K sev/Ca. At 24 °C, severing is not detected until 1.0 × 10−5m and is half-maximal at 1.9 × 10−5mCa2+ (Fig. 1 C). The latter value agrees with those reported by others at room temperature (20Kinosian H.J. Newman J. Lincoln B. Selden L.A. Gershman L.C. Estes J.E Biophy. J. 1998; 75: 3092-3100Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar, 21Lamb J.A. Allen P.G. Tuan B.Y. Janmey P.A J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 8999-9004Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Because the rate of gelsolin severing at 24 °C is highly Ca2+-dependent (20Kinosian H.J. Newman J. Lincoln B. Selden L.A. Gershman L.C. Estes J.E Biophy. J. 1998; 75: 3092-3100Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar, 22Allen P.G. Janmey P.A J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 32916-32923Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), the 10-fold increase in apparent K sev/Ca probably reflects the fact that severing has not reached steady state at 24 °C (20Kinosian H.J. Newman J. Lincoln B. Selden L.A. Gershman L.C. Estes J.E Biophy. J. 1998; 75: 3092-3100Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). Limited proteolysis is used to determine whether gelsolin conformation is affected by temperature. For these studies, we use plasmin that cleaves gelsolin in a Ca2+- and disulfide bond-dependent manner (26Wen D. Corina K. Chow E.P. Miller S. Janmey P.A. Pepinsky R.B Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 9700-9709Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). As reported previously (13Pope B.J. Gooch J.T. Weeds A.G Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 15848-15855Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar,26Wen D. Corina K. Chow E.P. Miller S. Janmey P.A. Pepinsky R.B Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 9700-9709Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar), plasmin cleaves reduced and oxidized gelsolin after Lys150 (in S2) to generate a 70-kDa fragment in EGTA (Fig.2 A, lanes 4 and5). In Ca2+ and at 37 °C, plasmin cleaves non-disulfide-bonded gelsolin further into a 65-kDa fragment (after R228 in S2) and , to a smaller extent, a 45-kDa fragment (after Lys367 in the S3–4 linker) (lane 2). It does not cleave disulfide-bonded gelsolin at R228 (lane 3). In contrast, at 24 °C and in Ca2+, plasmin does not cleave reduced gelsolin at R228 (Fig. 2 B, comparelanes 2 and 6 with lanes 3 and7). The difference in plasmin sensitivity at 37 °C and that at 24 °C suggests that room temperature stabilizes non-disulfide-bonded gelsolin S2 in an inactive conformation resembling that of disulfide-bonded S2. This may account for the low severing activity at 24 °C. We cannot explain at present why our results contradict a previous study finding that disulfide bonding enhances Ca2+ activation of severing (27Allen P.G FEBS Lett. 1997; 401: 89-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). Our results stress the importance of studying gelsolin at 37 °C and establish that gelsolin can be activated to sever actin filaments at physiologically relevant submicromolar Ca2+ concentration and temperature. We reported previously that gelsolin with C-terminal deletion to residue 738 (GS738) severs actin much more weakly in 1 mm EGTA than in 0.2 mm Ca2+, whereas GS732 is fully active in EGTA (10Kwiatkowski D. Janmey P.A. Yin H.L J. Cell Biol. 1989; 108: 1717-1726Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar). These residues are part of the S6 tail (Fig. 1 A). GS738 is missing the tail helix and part of the tail loop, whereas GS732 is missing the entire tail (12Burtnick L.D. Koepf E.K. Grimes J. Jones E.Y. Stuart D.I. McLaughlin P.J. Robinson R.C Cell. 1997; 90: 661-670Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar). Although these previous results were frequently cited to support the latch hypothesis (13Pope B.J. Gooch J.T. Weeds A.G Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 15848-15855Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 20Kinosian H.J. Newman J. Lincoln B. Selden L.A. Gershman L.C. Estes J.E Biophy. J. 1998; 75: 3092-3100Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar), the apparently wild type behavior of the tail helix truncated GS738 actually contradicts the current model. In light of the recent findings that gelsolin has micromolar and submicromolar affinity Ca2+-binding sites (18Pope B. Maciver S. Weeds A Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 1583-1588Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar) and that the rate of severing is highly Ca2+ dependent (20Kinosian H.J. Newman J. Lincoln B. Selden L.A. Gershman L.C. Estes J.E Biophy. J. 1998; 75: 3092-3100Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar, 22Allen P.G. Janmey P.A J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 32916-32923Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we re-examined this issue. We studied the behavior of gelsolin missing only the tail helix (GS744), the tail helix and part of the tail loop (GS738), or the entire tail (GS732) in a range of Ca2+concentrations. The Ca2+ response curve of GS744 is dramatically shifted to the left compared with full-length gelsolin. At 37 °C, GS744 has 20% maximum severing activity in EGTA and is already 65% active at 6 × 10−8m Ca2+ (Fig.1 B). At 24 °C, GS744 is 48% active at 6 × 10−8m Ca2+ (Fig. 1 C). Similar results were obtained with GS738 (data not shown). Thus deletion of the tail helix alone (GS744) is sufficient to lower the Ca2+ requirement for severing and to minimize the difference between 37 °C and 24 °C. We conclude that 10−6m Ca2+ is required for tail helix unlatching or the conformational change immediately after unlatching, and these processes are more efficient at 37 °C. As shown previously, GS732 severs independently of Ca2+ at both temperatures. Because tail helix deletion decreases the Ca2+ requirement for severing by more than 30-fold (from 2.2 × 10−6to 0.06 × 10−6m), the tail helix must have a primary role in the Ca2+ regulation of severing. This may be achieved through a tail to S2 blockage (the latch mechanism) or through a direct effect on the C-half. To distinguish between these possibilities, we tested the effect of tail deletion on the Ca2+ dependence of the gelsolin C-half interaction with actin monomers. C-half binding to actin monomers is reflected in an increase in the critical concentration (C c) for actin polymerization (30Kwiatkowski D. Janmey P.A. Mole J. Yin H.L J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 15232-15238Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). CT755 (wild type C-terminal half) binds actin in the presence of Ca2+ (as reflected by the increase inC c at the x intercept) but does not bind actin in EGTA (no increase in C c above the actin control) (Fig. 3 A). Likewise, CT738 and CT744 bind actin monomer only in the presence of Ca2+ (Fig. 3 B). In contrast, CT732 binds actin equally well in Ca2+ or EGTA (Fig. 3 A). Ca2+ titration shows that CT755, CT744, and CT738 are already active at 4 × 10−6mCa2+, and all are half-maximally active at around 10−6m Ca2+ (Fig. 3 C). Thus, deletion of the tail helix and part of the tail loop (to residues 744 and 738) has minimal effect on the Ca2+ requirement for C-half binding to actin. The reduced Ca2+ requirement for severing by the corresponding gelsolins is not due to Ca2+-independent activation of the C-half per se. Deletion of the entire tail (CT732) generates Ca2+-independent actin binding (Fig. 3, B andC), suggesting that tail loop residues between Trp732 and Asp737 contribute to Ca2+ regulation of the C-half but in a different way that is not yet understood. Intrinsic tryptophan fluorescence was used to monitor conformational changes at 37 °C. Ca2+ induces a dose-dependent and saturable decrease in fluorescence without shifting the emission maximum at 320 nm (data not shown). A plot of fluorescence quenching versus Ca2+reveals a three-component response (Fig.4 A). The first two components are saturable (Fig. 4, B and C). The third approaches saturability at above 1 × 10−5m (Fig. 4 A). There is a hint that fluorescence may continue to rise at greater than 1 × 10−4m. This may be attributed to nonspecific binding at unphysiologically high Ca2+ concentrations. The apparentK d for Ca2+ of the three components are 0.1 × 10−6, 0.3 × 10−6, and 6.3 × 10−6m, respectively (TableI). The first two values are within the range of the gelsolin submicromolar Ca2+-binding sites (9McLaughlin P.J. Gooch J.T. Mannherz H.-G. Weeds A.G. 31P NMR spectroscopy has been used to show that the activity of RNase A, which is lowered in the presence of urea, can be recovered with trimethylamine-N-oxide (TMAO). A 1:1 ratio of TMAO:urea was sufficient to recover the enzyme activity. 1H nuclear Overhauser effect spectroscopy NMR studies with RNase A have shown that even at relatively low effective concentrations of TMAO, some modification of the three-dimensional structure of the biomolecule is apparent. 31P NMR spectroscopy has been used to show that the activity of RNase A, which is lowered in the presence of urea, can be recovered with trimethylamine-N-oxide (TMAO). A 1:1 ratio of TMAO:urea was sufficient to recover the enzyme activity. 1H nuclear Overhauser effect spectroscopy NMR studies with RNase A have shown that even at relatively low effective concentrations of TMAO, some modification of the three-dimensional structure of the biomolecule is apparent. trimethylamine-N-oxide nuclear Overhauser effect spectroscopy polyuridylic acid uridine 2′,3′-cyclic phosphate poly(U)-3′-(uridyl-2′,3′-cyclic phosphate) Many organisms are known to accumulate small organic molecules (osmolytes) in their tissues in response to external osmotic stresses such as dehydration, freezing, or high salinity. For example, the tissues of cartilaginous fishes characteristically contain high levels of urea, as part of a strategem for increasing blood osmolality in seawater. (1Bedford J.J. Harper J.H. Leader J.P. Yancey P.H. Smith R.A.J. Comp. Biochem. Physiol. B. 1998; 119: 521-526Crossref Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 2Bedford J.J. Harper J.H. Leader J.P. Smith R.A.J. J. Comp. Physiol. 1998; 168: 123-131Crossref Scopus (15) Google Scholar) It is generally known that urea can denature biological macromolecules (3Yancey P.H. Somero G.N. Biochem. J. 1979; 183: 317-323Crossref PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar, 4Wang A. Bolen D.W. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 9101-9108Crossref PubMed Scopus (396) Google Scholar); however, this effect can be offset by maintaining a cellular environment rich in “counteracting osmolytes,” particularly trimethylamine-N-oxide (TMAO)1 and glycine betaine (3Yancey P.H. Somero G.N. Biochem. J. 1979; 183: 317-323Crossref PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar, 4Wang A. Bolen D.W. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 9101-9108Crossref PubMed Scopus (396) Google Scholar, 5Burg M.B. Peters E.M. Am. J. Physiol. 1998; 274: F762-F765PubMed Google Scholar). There is much interest (4Wang A. Bolen D.W. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 9101-9108Crossref PubMed Scopus (396) Google Scholar, 6Lin T.-Y. Timasheff S.N. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 12695-12701Crossref PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar) in understanding the way in which counteracting osmolytes such as TMAO might offset the effects of urea on the function and/or conformation of enzymes. The present work seeks to address this issue by examining the (in vitro) effects of urea and TMAO on both the activity and three-dimensional structure of a model protein, based on NMR spectroscopy. Bovine pancreatic ribonuclease A (RNase A) was selected as the model in this study, as it is a well characterized protein (7Santoro J. Gonzalez C. Bruix M. Niera J.L. Nieto J.L. Herranz J. Rico M. J. Mol. Biol. 1993; 229: 722-734Crossref PubMed Scopus (155) Google Scholar, 8Raines R.T. Chem. Rev. 1998; 98: 1045-1065Crossref PubMed Scopus (819) Google Scholar) whose NMR spectrum has been fully analyzed. (9Rico M. Bruix M. Santoro J. Gonzalez C. Niera J.L. Nieto J.L. Herranz J. Eur. J. Biochem. 1989; 183: 623-638Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar) In addition, RNase A has previously been used in studies of counteraction of urea destabilization by methylamines. (3Yancey P.H. Somero G.N. Biochem. J. 1979; 183: 317-323Crossref PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar) Although RNase A is not derived from tissues, which normally experience high urea concentrations, the counteracting osmolyte hypothesis is proposed (4Wang A. Bolen D.W. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 9101-9108Crossref PubMed Scopus (396) Google Scholar, 5Burg M.B. Peters E.M. Am. J. Physiol. 1998; 274: F762-F765PubMed Google Scholar) to be a general one, extending to proteins that are not subjected to high concentrations of urea in vivo. Ribonuclease A (type XIIA), polyuridylic acid, trimethylamine-N-oxide (Sigma), and urea (BDH) were used without further purification. 31P NMR assays were carried out at 25 °C in either a 0.1 mimidazole·HCl buffer (pH 6.98) or a 50 mm potassium hydrogen phthalate buffer (pH 3.98) containing NaCl (0.2m), poly(U) (6 mm in P–O5′ bonds), urea (0–2 m), TMAO (0–1 m), and RNase (0.1 μm for pH 6.98, 2 μm for pH 3.98). Each reaction was monitored for 11–12 h. Data were collected on a Varian Unity Inova spectrometer, operating at 202.299 mHz, using the following parameters: pulse width, 90°; acquisition time, 1.594 s; relaxation delay, 0.5 s; number of transients, 256; sweep width, 14215 Hz.31P NMR spectra were referenced (δ = 0 ppm) to external H3PO4 (0.3 m). Relative integrated intensities of the poly(U) peak were measured as a function of time and these data were fitted (R > 98%) to an exponential function using Excel®. The lifetimes, listed in Table I, were determined when the peak was 50% of the original intensity. Experimental conditions: 0.1 m imidazole · HCl buffer + 0.2 m NaCl, pH 6.98, RNase concentration 0.1 μm. 6 mm poly(U) implies a concentration of 6 mm in P–O5′ bonds. Samples of RNase A for1H NMR NOESY spectra were prepared in 95% H2O, 5% D2O (1.25 mm) and adjusted to pH 4 by the addition of small amounts of HCl. Sodium 3-trimethylsilyl-2,2,3,3-d 4-propionate (1 mm) was added as the internal reference (δ = 0 ppm). Spectra were acquired on the Varian Unity Inova spectrometer, operating at 499.7393 MHz at 35 °C, in the phase-sensitive mode, with the carrier frequency at the middle of the spectrum. A mixing time of 0.15 s was used, and spectra were collected with 16 transients and 128 increments. Water suppression was achieved using the WETNOESY (10Ogg R.J. Kingsley P.B. Taylor J.S. J. Magn. Reson. 1994; 104: 1-10Crossref Scopus (532) Google Scholar) pulse sequence. NOESY spectra were interpreted with the aid of the search program BBReader, (11Wimmer R. Muller N. Petersen S.B. J. Biomol. NMR. 1997; 9: 101-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar) which assigned NOESY cross-peaks to the protons of particular amino acid residues. The reference structure data file (2aas.pdb) was obtained from the Protein Data Bank (12Berman H.M. Westbrook J. Feng Z. Gilliland G. Bhat T.N. Weissig H. Shindyalov I.N. Bourne P.E. Nucleic Acids Res. 2000; 28: 235-242Crossref PubMed Scopus (24367) Google Scholar), and hydrogens were added using the MOLMOL program (13Koradi R. Billeter M. Wüthrich K. J. Mol. Graphics. 1996; 14: 51-55Crossref PubMed Scopus (6304) Google Scholar). The reference NMR data file (bmr443.str, accession no. 443) was obtained from the BioMagResBank. Major peak deletions are listed in Table II and, in addition, the following changes were noted: 15 mm TMAO: Glu49 HA-Ser50 H, Gln28HA-Gln28 H, Val63 HG1-Val63 HA; 30 mm TMAO: Glu49 HA-Ser50 H, Gln28 H-Met30 HB2/HB3, Val57HB-Val57 HA, (Thr45 HB-Thr45 H); 45 mm TMAO, Gln28 H-Met30 HB2/HB3, Gln28 HA-Gln28 H, (Thr45HB-Thr45 H), (Tyr97 HA-Lys98 H), (Val47 HB-Thr82 H). Data in parentheses have confidence levels <85%. Assignments using BBReader (14Holland L.Z. McFall-Ngai M. Somero G.N. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 3207-3215Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Confidence levels (i.e. BBReader calculated “score”) >85%. Nomenclature as in BioMagResBank. The proposed mechanism for the general reaction of RNase A with RNA (Scheme FS1) (8Raines R.T. Chem. Rev. 1998; 98: 1045-1065Crossref PubMed Scopus (819) Google Scholar) involves enzyme-catalyzed formation of cyclic phosphodiester intermediates, which are transformed ultimately to a monomeric phosphate species. The key amino acid residues involved in the process are His12 and His119. It has been shown that the RNase A-catalyzed hydrolysis of polyuridylic acid (poly(U)) can be monitored by 31P NMR spectroscopy. (15Thompson J.E. Venegas F.D. Raines R.T. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 7408-7414Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar, 16delCardayre S.B. Raines R.T. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 6031-6037Crossref PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar) The present work uses 31P NMR as an assay method for determining the effects of osmolytes on the first (transphorylation) step of the reaction, by examining the rate of removal of poly(U) from the reaction mixture. 31P NMR spectra collected at different time intervals during the reaction show four groups of 31P resonances, corresponding to the presence of: polyuridylic acid (poly(U)), uridine 2′,3′-cyclic phosphate (U>p), poly(U)-3′-(uridyl-2′, 3′-cyclic phosphate) (poly (U)U>p), and uridine 3′-phosphate (15Thompson J.E. Venegas F.D. Raines R.T. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 7408-7414Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). Representative 31P spectra, collected at time intervals during the RNase A-catalyzed hydrolysis of poly(U), are displayed in Fig. 1. The resonances correlate well with published data (15Thompson J.E. Venegas F.D. Raines R.T. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 7408-7414Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar) and are assigned as shown. Before the addition of RNase A, the peak assigned to poly(U) is observed as a sharp singlet; however, in spectra collected after the addition of the enzyme, a family of peaks is observed in this region, reflecting the increasing size heterogeneity of the poly(U) chain. Similarly, after the initiation of the reaction a group of peaks is seen in the spectral region assigned to poly(U)U>p. Fig. 2 shows a set of four spectra corresponding to separate reaction mixtures containing either urea, urea + TMAO, or no osmolytes. A comparison of these spectra with those in Fig. 1 shows clearly that the intermediate species formed during the RNase A-catalyzed reaction are also produced in the presence of TMAO and urea. Thus it seems reasonable to assume that the general mechanism of the reaction is the same in each case. The spectra in Fig. 2 were obtained with comparable initial concentrations of poly(U) and RNase A, at a convenient time (21 min) after reaction initiation. In the unmodified system (Fig. 2 A), resonances are observed for poly(U) and the cyclic phosphate intermediates poly(U)U>p and U>p. However, in the presence of 1 m urea (Fig. 2 B), only a relatively small amount of U>p is observed at the same time. Because U>p is the second identifiable species formed during the course of the reaction, the hydrolysis in this case is proceeding more slowly than in the unmodified situation. Spectra obtained from reaction mixtures containing both TMAO and urea (Figs. 2, C andD) are similar to the original (Fig. 2 A), which demonstrates that although the activity of RNase is modified in the presence of urea, this effect is counteracted by TMAO. To examine the effects of different osmolyte concentrations and ratios on the reactivity of RNase A, a series of 31P NMR experiments were conducted with varying concentrations of urea and TMAO. To facilitate comparisons, a “lifetime” of poly(U) was used, representing the time required for the relative integral of the combined poly(U) resonances to reduce by half. The results shown (TableI) are the mean of either two or three experiments. From Table I it is evident that as the concentration of urea is increased and the lifetime of poly(U) also increases (entry 1versus entries 2–5). However, at constant concentration of urea (entries 6–8 and 9–11), the lifetime decreases with increasing TMAO concentration, such that for 1:1 urea:TMAO, the original (entry 1) reactivity is recovered. This result is observed for both of the urea concentrations (700 mm and 1 m) examined. Interestingly, in the presence of TMAO alone (entry 12), the lifetime is decreased relative to the osmolyte-free case, which demonstrates that, at least under these reaction conditions, TMAO itself does affect RNase A activity. The 31P NMR results presented here do not show a correlation between urea concentration and the rate of the last step,viz. U>p → uridine 3′-phosphate, in the reaction sequence. It has been proposed (15Thompson J.E. Venegas F.D. Raines R.T. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 7408-7414Crossref PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar) that after the first (transphorylation) step, the substrate is released from the enzyme active site before further reaction. This release takes place even though the two histidine residues (His12 and His119) are appropriately protonated and in position for the next step in the reaction. As the final step is not dependent upon U>p being associated with the enzyme, it follows that the rate of production of uridine 3′-phosphate should not be influenced by enzyme activity, provided appropriate concentrations of intermediates are maintained. A set of 31P NMR assays was also performed at pH 3.98 to allow comparison with the results of structural studies (see below). In concert with the data obtained at pH 6.98, it is found that the lifetime for poly(U) concentration is increased in the presence of urea, compared with the unmodified case; however, TMAO shows no counteracting effect. This observation may reflect that TMAO is mostly protonated at pH 4 (see “Discussion”). Considerations of the mode of action of counteracting osmolytes on proteins have focused on whether there is a direct protein-osmolyte interaction (4Wang A. Bolen D.W. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 9101-9108Crossref PubMed Scopus (396) Google Scholar, 6Lin T.-Y. Timasheff S.N. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 12695-12701Crossref PubMed Scopus (322) Google Scholar) or an indirect, solvent-mediated (“water structuring”) effect (17Yancey P.H. Clark M.E. Hand S.C. Bowlus R.D. Somero G.N. Science. 1982; 217: 1214-1222Crossref PubMed Scopus (2868) Google Scholar). The present work uses two-dimensional 1H NOESY NMR studies to probe aspects of the action of TMAO on RNase A. 1H NMR has previously been used to determine the solution structure of RNase A (9Rico M. Bruix M. Santoro J. Gonzalez C. Niera J.L. Nieto J.L. Herranz J. Eur. J. Biochem. 1989; 183: 623-638Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar), and the data are available on the Protein Data Bank (12Berman H.M. Westbrook J. Feng Z. Gilliland G. Bhat T.N. Weissig H. Shindyalov I.N. Bourne P.E. Nucleic Acids Res. 2000; 28: 235-242Crossref PubMed Scopus (24367) Google Scholar) and BioMagResBank. Hence, this protein is a convenient model for NOESY studies. The structural characterization of RNase A relies heavily on NOESY spectra, and the search program BBReader (11Wimmer R. Muller N. Petersen S.B. J. Biomol. NMR. 1997; 9: 101-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar) used in the present study, has been developed to search such data. The 1H NOESY NMR spectrum of RNase A was found to match that described previously (9Rico M. Bruix M. Santoro J. Gonzalez C. Niera J.L. Nieto J.L. Herranz J. Eur. J. Biochem. 1989; 183: 623-638Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar), obtained under the same experimental conditions. NOESY spectra of RNase A were then collected in the presence of varying concentrations of osmolytes and compared with the osmolyte-free spectra. Cross-peaks which were removed (“deleted”) from the baseline spectrum by the addition of the osmolyte indicated the particular hydrogen-hydrogen internuclear distance had increased to over 6 Å. The deletions were assigned to specific amino acid residues using a BBReader, and therefore it was possible to determine which regions of the RNase A molecule were affected. Similar experiments have been reported with a hen egg white lysozyme/sorbitol system. (19Wimmer R. Olsson M. Neves Petersen M.T. Hatti-Kaul R. Petersen S.B. Muller N. J. Biotechnol. 1997; 55: 85-100Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar) Spectra obtained with the relatively high concentrations of urea used in the 31P NMR assays were inconclusive because of difficulties in obtaining useful data. NOESY spectra of mixtures of RNase A and lower concentrations of urea did not show any discernable effects. The study therefore focused on an examination of the influence of TMAO alone, and Table II summarizes the persistent and reproducible deletions from the NOESY spectra over the range of TMAO concentrations examined and the related internuclear distances in the unmodified enzyme. The first two TMAO-induced spectral deletions (Table II) correspond to sequential contacts but, notably, the latter two indicate substantial increases (>2 Å) in the natural hydrogen-hydrogen internuclear distances between two β-sheets and also between a helix and a sheet in RNase A. Depending on the TMAO concentration, additional deletions were observed (cf. “Experimental Procedures”). Most of the data were assigned with a confidence level of greater than 85% as determined from percentage “scores” calculated by the BBReader program, on the basis both of the closeness of the chemical shift values to those in the published data, and of the distance between the two protons. These additional deletions were all short range intraresidue, sequential or i, i+2 contacts and as such do not provide additional structural information. Two histidine residues (His12 and His119) have been identified in the active site of RNase A (8Raines R.T. Chem. Rev. 1998; 98: 1045-1065Crossref PubMed Scopus (819) Google Scholar) and are therefore of interest for catalytic activity. None of the deletions noted involve either of these histidine residues. Furthermore, the NOESY spectrum of RNase A shows a cross-peak, which can be confidently (94%) assigned to a correlation between His119 H and Phe120 HA protons. This peak is not altered by the addition of TMAO, suggesting that the osmolyte does not have a direct interaction at this active site area. However, there is some indication that at least one of the subsite regions (viz. Thr45, located in the B1 subsite (8Raines R.T. Chem. Rev. 1998; 98: 1045-1065Crossref PubMed Scopus (819) Google Scholar)) is modified by the presence of TMAO. The effects of TMAO and other osmolytes on some of the physical properties of RNase A have been well documented (3Yancey P.H. Somero G.N. Biochem. J. 1979; 183: 317-323Crossref PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar, 5Burg M.B. Peters E.M. Am. J. Physiol. 1998; 274: F762-F765PubMed Google Scholar). For example, Burg and Peters (5Burg M.B. Peters E.M. Am. J. Physiol. 1998; 274: F762-F765PubMed Google Scholar) have shown that urea lowers the midpoint of thermal transition (Tm ) of RNase A, whereas glycerophosphocholine and TMAO counteract this effect. Yancey and Somero (3Yancey P.H. Somero G.N. Biochem. J. 1979; 183: 317-323Crossref PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar) also noted that TMAO and β-alanine increaseTm and that this structure stabilization occurs even at relatively low concentrations (∼0.1 m) (3Yancey P.H. Somero G.N. Biochem. J. 1979; 183: 317-323Crossref PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar). The previous results are in concert with the findings reported here. However, the NMR data provide information at a more detailed molecular level and show that the reactivity of the enzyme is decreased in the presence of urea but is clearly recovered in urea/TMAO mixtures. Furthermore, it has long been postulated that the ratio of TMAO:urea is significant and that an approximate 1:2 molar ratio often gives optimal counteraction (3Yancey P.H. Somero G.N. Biochem. J. 1979; 183: 317-323Crossref PubMed Scopus (305) Google Scholar, 20Burg M.B. Peters E.M. Am. J. Physiol. 1997; 273: F1048-F1053PubMed Google Scholar, 21Burg M.B. Kwon E.D. Peters E.M. Kidney Int. 1996; 50 Suppl. 57: 100-104Google Scholar). Under the experimental conditions used in this work, a 1:1 ratio is found to be sufficient to recover the activity of RNase A. To base the NOESY analysis on the established data, it was necessary to obtain spectra under the same experimental conditions. In particular, measurements at pH 4 were required. It should be noted that at this pH, most of the TMAO (pK a 5.13 (22Perrin D.D. Dissociation Constants of Organic Bases in Aqueous Solution. Butterworth & Co. Ltd., London1965: 32Google Scholar)) is in the protonated conjugate acid form and the counteracting effect was not apparent (see above). Notwithstanding these limitations, the NOESY experiments indicate that, even at low effective concentrations, TMAO can cause detectable structural changes in some segments of the enzyme. This contrasts with the hen egg white lysozyme study, where a much larger concentration of the perturbing compound was required to induce any observable changes (19Wimmer R. Olsson M. Neves Petersen M.T. Hatti-Kaul R. Petersen S.B. Muller N. J. Biotechnol. 1997; 55: 85-100Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). In that case, two new cross-peaks were observed in the NOESY spectrum, and some chemical shift changes were also noted. As noted above, there are at least two ways in which TMAO might influence enzyme structure and activity. These include a direct osmolyte-protein interaction or a solvent-mediated effect that induces a “global” change in the environment around the protein. For example, it has been proposed that organic osmolytes can influence hydrogen bonding of solvent molecules over long distances (18Zeidler M.D. Franks F. Water: A Comprehensive Treatise. 2. Plenum, New York1973: 529Google Scholar). This work has shown that TMAO alone at pH 4 does not induce changes in the RNase molecule at or near the active site, and at best, minor structural structural changes are introduced in other regions of the molecule. The osmolyte has a more dispersed, global effect on the protein, which is presumably effected via the solvent, rather than a specific interaction at particular site(s). In summary, by using 31P NMR spectroscopy, it has been demonstrated unequivocally that the activity of RNase A, lowered in the presence of urea, can be recovered with TMAO in molar ratios of approximately 1:1. NOESY studies with RNase A have shown that even at relatively low effective concentrations of TMAO some, albeit small, changes in the three-dimensional structure of the biomolecule can be detected. Minor changes in protein structure at locations outside the active site have been postulated previously to affect kinetic properties (14Holland L.Z. McFall-Ngai M. Somero G.N. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 3207-3215Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). We are grateful to Dr. C. R. Clark and Dr. R. Wimmer for helpful discussions.

According to quantum mechanics, matter can be regarded as waves. ‘Matter waves’ made from composite particles known as polaritons, which are part light and part matter, can be amplified in a semiconductor to produce a matter-wave analogue of a laser amplifier.

Many cosubstrates for the peroxidase activity of prostaglandin H synthase-1 (PGHS-1) have been reported to produce a large (2–7-fold) increase in the cyclooxygenase velocity in addition to a substantial increase in the number of cyclooxygenase catalytic turnovers. The large stimulation of cyclooxygenase velocity has become an important criterion for evaluation of putative PGHS reaction mechanisms. This criterion has been a major weakness of branched-chain tyrosyl radical mechanisms, which correctly predict many other cyclooxygenase characteristics. Our computer simulations based on a branched-chain mechanism indicated that the uncorrected oxygen electrode signals commonly used to monitor activity can seriously overestimate the effects of cosubstrate on cyclooxygenase velocity. The simulation results prompted re-examination of the effect of several cosubstrates (phenol, acetaminophen,N,N,N′,N′-tetramethylphenylenediamine, and Trolox) on PGHS-1 cyclooxygenase velocity. Cyclooxygenase kinetics were examined at reduced temperature or elevated pH, where the oxygen electrode signal can be corrected to provide reliable oxygen consumption trajectories. The cosubstrates produced only a slight (10–60%) stimulation of the cyclooxygenase velocity. Peroxidase cosubstrates thus have a much smaller stimulatory effect on cyclooxygenase velocity than previously reported. This corrects a longstanding misperception of cosubstrate effects, provides more realistic kinetic constraints on PGHS mechanisms, and removes what was a major deficiency of branched-chain tyrosyl radical mechanisms. Garavito R.M. DeWitt D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 33157-33160Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1835) Google Scholar, 2Kulmacz R.J. DeWitt D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 33157-33160Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1835) Google Scholar). The PGHS peroxidase catalytic cycle resembles that of other heme-dependent peroxidases: the ferric heme of the resting enzyme is oxidized to Intermediate I (Compound I) by reaction with peroxide, and electron-donating cosubstrates complete the peroxidase catalytic cycle by reducing Intermediate I to Compound II and then to resting enzyme (3Lambeir A.-M. Markey C.M. Dunford H.B. Marnett L.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 14894-14896Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Endogenous peroxidase cosubstrates, such as uric acid, are present in cell cytosol (4Ogino N. Yamamoto S. Hayaishi O. Tokuyama T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. The protective action of cellular reductants greatly increases the number of catalytic turnovers before cyclooxygenase self-inactivation, thereby increasing the capacity for synthesis of potent lipid mediators (14Marshall P.J. Kulmacz R.J. Lands W.E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 3510-3517Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). For its part, the large stimulation of cyclooxygenase velocity by cosubstrate has become a defining characteristic of catalytic behavior and an important criterion for evaluation of potential PGHS reaction mechanisms (11Hemler M.E. Lands W.E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 6253-6261Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Hsuanyu Y. Dunford H.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 17649-17657Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Wei C. Kulmacz R.J. Tsai A.-L. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 8499-8512Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Many mechanistic schemes have been devised to account for stimulation of cyclooxygenase velocity. One strategy has been to suggest that the reductive action of cosubstrates retrieves enzyme from catalytically unproductive oxidized intermediates (11Hemler M.E. Lands W.E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 6253-6261Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Hsuanyu Y. Dunford H.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 17649-17657Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar,16Bakovic M. Dunford H.B. Prostaglandins Leukotrienes Essent. Fatty Acids. 1996; 54: 341-349Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar), but plausible mechanisms adopting this approach have generally not been tested for their quantitative kinetic predictions. Another approach proposed a catalytic role for cosubstrate in the cyclooxygenase active site (17Kulmacz R.J. Pendleton R.B. Lands W.E.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 5527-5536Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), but simultaneous binding of cosubstrate and arachidonate seems at odds with spatial constraints at the top of the cyclooxygenase channel in crystallographic models (18Picot D. Loll P.J. Garavito R.M. Nature. 1994; 367: 243-249Crossref PubMed Scopus (1141) Google Scholar, 19Luong C. Miller A. Barnett J. Chow J. Ramesha C. Browner M.F. Nat. Struct. Isakson P.C. Stallings W.C. Nastainczyk W. Ruf H.H. Eur. J. Biochem. 1988; 171: 321-328Crossref PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar, 22Shimokawa T. Kulmacz R.J. DeWitt D.L. Smith W.L. J. Biol.
