Stable cell lines expressing either full-length or truncated forms of FAK were isolated after transfection of the FAK-deficient 3B6 variant cells. The NH2 domain of FAK, which lacks the enzymatic and the COOH-terminal regions, was sufficient to reconstitute secretion. The different truncated forms of FAK were still tyrosine-phosphorylated after FcεRI aggregation. Therefore, the kinase domain and the COOH-terminal region are not essential for FcεRI-induced tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK or for secretion. Taken together, our data demonstrate that the reconstitution of secretion is dissociated from FAK activation and that the NH2-terminal region of FAK is the only critical element that may play a role in FcεRI-induced secretion by acting as an adaptor or linker molecule. protein-tyrosine kinase focal adhesion kinase pp125FAK high affinity IgE receptor hemagglutinin sequence rat basophilic leukemia cells COOH-terminal-deleted FAK NH2-terminal region of FAK NH2-terminal-deleted FAK FAK-related non-kinase c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase mitogen-activated protein antigen polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis Integrins are cell surface receptors that bind to extracellular matrix proteins such as fibronectin, laminin, or vitronectin. Integrin-dependent adhesion triggers the activation of a complex signaling cascade that functions to control cell morphogenesis, migration, and proliferation (1Gilmore A.P. Romer L.H. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1996; 7: 1209-1224Crossref PubMed Scopus (461) Google Scholar). A number of protein-tyrosine kinases (PTK)1 are involved in integrin-regulated signaling. Among them, the focal adhesion kinase FAK colocalizes with focal adhesions and is tyrosine-phosphorylated upon cell adherence on fibronectin (2Schaller M.D. Borgman C.A. Cobb B.S. Vines R.R. Reynolds A.B. Parsons J.T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 5192-5196Crossref PubMed Scopus (1280) Google Scholar). In various cell types, FAK functions in transmitting an integrin-dependent signal, leading to the control of cell motility, cell adherence, cell proliferation, or the prevention of cells from activating the apoptosis process (3Illc D. Furuta Y. Kanazawa S. Takeda N. Sobue K. Nakatsuji N. Nomura S. Fujimoto J. Okada M. Yamamoto T. Aizawa S. Nature. 1995; 377: 539-544Crossref PubMed Scopus (1576) Google Scholar, 4Maung K. Easty D.J. Hill S.P. Bennett D.C. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 6824-6828Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar, 5Oktay M. Wary K.K. Dans M. Birge R.B. Giancotti F.G. J. Cell Biol. 1999; 145: 1461-1469Crossref PubMed Scopus (247) Google Scholar). Recently, a homologue of FAK, Dfak56, has been identified in Drosophila melanogaster (6Fox G.L. Rebay I. Hynes R.O. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 14978-14983Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar, 7Palmer R.H. Fessler L.I. Edeen P.T. Madigan S.J. McKeown M. Hunter T. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 35621-35629Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 8Fujimoto J. Sawamoto K. Okabe M. Takagi Y. Tezuka T. Yoshikawa S. Ryo H. Okano H. Yamamoto T. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 29196-29201Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). Dfak56 is expressed where Drosophila position-specific integrins are located and activated upon cell adherence, thus confirming the role of FAK in integrin-mediated signaling. Mammalian FAK is a 125-kDa non-receptor PTK, which has large NH2-terminal and COOH-terminal regions flanking the central catalytic domain (for review see Ref. 9Schlaepfer D.D. Hunter T. Trends Cell Biol. 1998; 8: 151-157Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (436) Google Scholar and Fig.1). The COOH-terminal region of FAK can bind a number of cytoskeletal and signaling molecules, which become tyrosine-phosphorylated after integrin activation. This region contains the focal adhesion targeting (FAT) sequence, which interacts with talin and paxillin and is thought to be essential for the activation and translocation of FAK to focal adhesion sites (10Hildebrand J.D. Schaller M.D. Parsons J.T. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 123: 993-1005Crossref PubMed Scopus (356) Google Scholar). The COOH-terminal domain of FAK also contains two proline-rich regions, which bind SH3-containing molecules, including the GTPase regulator associated with FAK (Graf) (11Hildebrand J.D. Taylor J.M. Parsons J.T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 3169-3178Crossref PubMed Scopus (293) Google Scholar) or P130Cas (12Harte M.T. Hildebrand J.D. Burnham M.R. Bouton A.H. Parsons J.T. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 13649-13655Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (321) Google Scholar), the latter being involved in the activation of JNK MAP kinases. Furthermore, the phosphorylation of several tyrosine residues in the COOH-terminal region generates binding sites for SH2 domain-containing signaling molecules such as the Shc·Grb2 complex, leading to the activation of the Ras-Erk MAP kinase pathway (13Schlaepfer D.D. Hunter T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 5623-5633Crossref PubMed Scopus (395) Google Scholar, 14Schlaepfer D.D. Hanks S.K. Hunter T. van der Geer P. Nature. 1994; 372: 786-791Crossref PubMed Scopus (1426) Google Scholar). In contrast, the function of the large NH2-terminal domain of FAK remains unclear. This domain, by directly or indirectly interacting with integrins, may regulate the adherence-induced FAK activation (15Schaller M.D. Otey C.A. Hildebrand J.D. Parsons J.T. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 130: 1181-1187Crossref PubMed Scopus (549) Google Scholar). The NH2-terminal region of FAK also contains the tyrosine residue Tyr397, which is critical for FAK activation. Clustering of β integrin is thought to enhance the phosphorylation of Tyr397, via an autophosphorylation process. Phosphorylated Tyr397 then recruits Src family kinases, which phosphorylate other sites on FAK such as Tyr407 in the NH2-terminal region, Tyr576 and Tyr577 in the activation loop (leading to an increase in FAK enzymatic activity) (16Calalb M.B. Polte T.R. Hanks S.K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 954-963Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), Tyr861 (17Calalb M.B. Zhang X.E. Polte T.R. Hanks S.K. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1996; 228: 662-668Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar), and Tyr925 (potential Grb2 binding site) in the COOH-terminal region (14Schlaepfer D.D. Hanks S.K. Hunter T. van der Geer P. Nature. 1994; 372: 786-791Crossref PubMed Scopus (1426) Google Scholar). The phosphorylated Tyr397 can also bind and activate other signaling molecules, including PTEN (18Tamura M. Gu J.G. Matsumoto K. Aota S. Parsons R. Yamada K.M. Science. 1998; 280: 1614-1617Crossref PubMed Scopus (1068) Google Scholar), phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (19Chen H.-C. Guan J.-L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 10148-10152Crossref PubMed Scopus (473) Google Scholar, 20Reiske H.R. Kao S.C. Cary L.A. Guan J.L. Lai J.F. Chen H.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 12361-12366Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar), Grb7 (21Han D.C. Guan J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 24425-24430Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (199) Google Scholar), and PLC-γ1 (22Zhang X. Chattopadhyay A. Ji Q.S. Owen J.D. Ruest P.J. Carpenter G. Hanks S.K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 9021-9026Crossref PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar). On basophils or mast cells, the aggregation of the high affinity IgE receptors (FcεRI) initiates biochemical events that result in degranulation and release of inflammatory mediators, like histamine or serotonin. The activation of FcεRI also increases the tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK in rat basophilic leukemia RBL-2H3 cells, a mast cell line that has been extensively used to study FcεRI-mediated secretion (23Hamawy M.M. Mergenhagen S. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 6851-6854Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). This receptor-induced phosphorylation of FAK and secretion from these cells are enhanced by adherence of the cells to fibronectin (23Hamawy M.M. Mergenhagen S. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 6851-6854Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 24Hamawy M.M. Oliver C. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Immunol. 1992; 149: 615-621PubMed Google Scholar). To define the role of FAK in secretion, we previously transfected FAK cDNA into a variant of the RBL-2H3 mast cell line (3B6 cells) that expressed low levels of this kinase and had decreased FcεRI-mediated but not Ca2+ ionophore-mediated secretion (25Hamawy M.M. Swieter M. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30498-30503Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). We observed that (i) FcεRI-induced histamine release is reconstituted in the 3B6 cells that expressed increased levels of wild type FAK, (ii) histamine release is also enhanced by the stable expression of two mutants of FAK: a kinase-inactive form in which the ATP binding site Lys454 is replaced by Arg or a mutant in which the Tyr397 autophosphorylation site is replaced by Phe, indicating that the catalytic activity and the autophosphorylation site of FAK are not essential for secretion (25Hamawy M.M. Swieter M. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30498-30503Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). FcεRI aggregation increased the tyrosine phosphorylation of both mutants of FAK to the same extent as did wild type FAK, indicating that other tyrosine kinases activated by FcεRI aggregation are phosphorylating FAK and some of these phosphorylation sites, which might interact with SH2-containing adaptor molecules, are other than Tyr397. This also suggests that the FcεRI-induced tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK is independent of a functional autophosphorylation site. To better understand how FAK modulates degranulation, we expressed different truncated forms of the molecule in the FAK-deficient 3B6 cells. We also used phosphorylation site-specific antibodies to examine the phosphorylation of FAK in these cells. Our results show that the NH2-terminal region of FAK was critical and substantial enough to reconstitute IgE-induced secretion in the 3B6 cells and that the kinase domain and the COOH-terminal region were not required to reconstitute degranulation. These results suggest that the role of FAK in secretion is unrelated to its activation and suggest that the NH2-terminal region of FAK has a major role in the regulation of some in vivo cell functions. Full-length mouse FAK cDNA was generously provided by Dr. S. Hanks (Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN). The pBS was purchased from Stratagene (La Jolla, CA), and the pSVL was from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech (Piscataway, NJ). A pBluescript vector containing the hemagglutinin sequence was kindly provided by Dr. Nicholas Ryba (NIDCR, National Institutes of Health). The pSV2-hph containing the hygromycin resistance gene and pSV2-Neo expressing the neomycin resistance gene were from ATCC (Rockville, MD). FAK monoclonal antibody was purchased from Transduction Laboratory (Lexington, KY). Anti-FAK rabbit polyclonal antibody directed against the COOH-terminal region of FAK was from Labvision Neomarkers (Fremont, CA), and the anti-phosphotyrosine antibody (4G10) was from Upstate Biotechnology, Inc. (Lake Placid, NY). Phosphorylation state site-specific FAK antibodies were purchased from BIOSOURCEInternational Inc. (Camarillo, CA). All other materials were obtained as described previously (26Basciano L.K. Berenstein E.H. Kmak L. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 11823-11831Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Full-length and the different truncated forms of FAK (Fig. 1) were prepared by polymerase chain reaction using Vent polymerase and the full-length FAK cDNA plasmid. The primers used were the following for full-length FAK (P1): 5′-TTG GTA CCG GGC CCT CTA GAA TGG CAG CTG CTT ATC TTG AC (containing KpnI and XbaI sites) and (P2): 5′-AGT GTG GCC GTG TCT GCC CTA G-3′. The COOH-terminal-deleted FAK product was obtained by using primers (P1) and 5′-ACC GTT CTT CTT GCT GCA CC-3′; NH2-terminal region of FAK with primers (P1) and 5′-AAT AAT CCC TGG TCG AGG GC-3′; NH2-terminal-deleted FAK with primers (P2) and 5′-TTG GTA CCG GGC CCT CTA GAC ACC ATG CCC TCG ACC AGG G-3′. FRNK was obtained by using primers (P2) and 5′-TTG GTA CCG GGC CCT CTA GAC ACC ATG GAA TCC AGA AGA CAG GC-3′. The hemagglutinin sequence was inserted into the pBluescript plasmid SK−between the EcoRV and BamHI sites. This plasmid (pBS-HA) was digested with EcoRV and KpnI. To add the HA-tagged sequence to each form of FAK, the polymerase chain reaction products were digested with KpnI and ligated into the pBS-HA plasmid. After verification of the constructs by DNA sequencing, the pBS plasmids containing the different FAK HA-cDNA sequences were digested with XbaI and BamHI and subcloned into the pSVL expression vector. RBL-2H3 cells have been characterized previously (27Barsumian E.L. Isersky C. Petrino M.G. Siraganian R.P. Eur. J. Immunol. 1981; 11: 317-323Crossref PubMed Scopus (481) Google Scholar). The RBL-2H3 cells were maintained in complete medium (Eagle's minimum essential medium with Earle's balanced salt solution supplemented with 15% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum, 4 mml-glutamine, and antibiotic-antimycotic mixture) at 37 °C in 5% CO2. The 3B6 cells were identified previously as cells in which the expression of FAK is 16 ± 9% as much as in the parental RBL-2H3 cells (25Hamawy M.M. Swieter M. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30498-30503Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). This cell line is resistant to G418 and is defective for FcεRI-mediated secretion, although release with the Ca2+ionophore is similar to that in the parental wild type cells. The 3B6 cells were cultured in complete medium containing 300 μg/ml (active concentration) of G418 (Geneticin, Life Technologies, Grand Island, NY). The monolayer cells were dissociated with 0.05% trypsin/0.53 mm EDTA and subcultured two to three times a week. The pSVL plasmids containing the cDNAs for wild type or variant forms of FAK and the pSV2-hph plasmid containing the hygromycin resistance gene were linearized. The expression vector and pSV2-hph plasmid at a ratio of 10:1 (55 μg total) were incubated with 3B6 cells (5 × 106) for 10 min on ice. After electroporation (Gene Pulser, Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA) at 960 microfarads, 310 millivolts, in Dulbecco's minimal essential medium, the cells were kept on ice for 10 min, and aliquots (5 × 105 cells) were transferred to ten 100-mm diameter tissue culture plates (Becton Dickinson, Lincoln Park, NJ). Selection (1.2 mg/ml hygromycin) was started 48 h after the transfection. Clones were identified, isolated using cloning rings, and expanded for testing. To transfect FRNK in RBL-2H3 cells, the pSV2-Neo plasmid expressing the neomycin resistance gene and pSVL plasmid containing FRNK were linearized and cotransfected (ratio 1:20) by electroporation into RBL-2H3 cells. Stable transfected clones were selected with 500 μg/ml active G418, and cell lines were screened for the expression of FRNK. All transfected cell lines were screened by immunoblotting, and 10 lines were further expanded that expressed truncated or wild type FAK. Briefly, cells were grown overnight at 37 °C in 24-well tissue culture plates (105 cells/well) and sensitized by culture with the anti-trinitrophenol-specific IgE. The following day, cells were washed two times in Eagle's minimum essential medium with Earle's balanced salt solution containing 0.1% bovine serum albumin plus Tris, 10 mm, pH 7.4. After the last wash, the cells were stimulated in this media with several concentrations of the antigen (Ag) dinitrophenol coupled to human serum albumin (48 molecules of dinitrophenol per molecule of human serum albumin) or with the Ca2+ ionophore A23187. After 45-min incubation at 37 °C, the supernatant was collected and analyzed for histamine as described previously (28Siraganian R.P. Anal. Biochem. 1974; 57: 383-394Crossref PubMed Scopus (660) Google Scholar). For immunoblotting of whole cell lysates, monolayer cells (105/well) were washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline and immediately lysed with hot sample buffer (75 mm Tris-HCl, pH 6.8, 2% SDS, 10% glycerol, 1% 2-mercaptoethanol). The cell lysates were boiled, and the proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE (Novex, San Diego, CA), transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membranes (Millipore, Bedford, MA) and blotted with the indicated antibodies. For the immunoprecipitation of FRNK, 5 × 106 cells were lysed in ice-cold Triton X-100 lysis buffer (1% Triton X-100, 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, 1 mmEGTA, 1 mm Na3VO4, 0.5 unit/ml aprotinin, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.5% Nonidet P-40) and mixed for 1 h at 4 °C with 3 μg of the anti-FAK mAb (clone 2A7; Upstate Biotechnology, Inc.) bound to 10 μg of rabbit anti-mouse Ig that had been preincubated for 2 h at 4 °C with 50 μl of protein A-agarose (Sigma, St Louis, MO). For immunoprecipitation of full-length FAK and the variant form ΔC-FAK, 5 × 106 cells were lysed with 1% hot SDS containing 1 mm Na3VO4 and 10 mmTris, pH 7.4. After boiling for 30 min, the lysates were diluted 1:10 with ice-cold Triton X-100 lysis buffer and mixed for 2 h at 4 °C with 2.5 μg of the anti-FAK mAb (Transduction Laboratory), which was bound to 10 μg of rabbit anti-mouse Ig that had been preincubated with protein A-agarose. For immunoprecipitation of the truncated forms N-FAK and ΔN-FAK, lysates from 5 × 106 cells, prepared and boiled as described above, were diluted 1:10 with ice-cold Triton X-100 lysis buffer and incubated with rabbit polyclonal anti-HA antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology Inc., Santa Cruz, CA) directly coupled to protein A-agarose beads. For all immunoprecipitation experiments, the cell lysates were incubated with the beads for 2 h at 4 °C. After three washes in ice-cold Triton X-100 lysis buffer, the beads were resuspended in SDS-PAGE sample buffer and boiled for 5 min. The proteins in the eluates were separated by SDS-PAGE, transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membranes, and blotted with the indicated antibodies. In all blots, proteins were visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence (Renaissance). In fibroblasts and other cell types, FAK activation by integrins leads to the phosphorylation of the tyrosine residue Tyr397, the autophosphorylation site. Once this site is phosphorylated, it becomes the binding site for Src family kinases, which then phosphorylate FAK on other tyrosine residues, including Tyr407 in the NH2 domain, Tyr577 in the activation loop, and several sites in the COOH-terminal domain, including Tyr861 (16Calalb M.B. Polte T.R. Hanks S.K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1995; 15: 954-963Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 17Calalb M.B. Zhang X.E. Polte T.R. Hanks S.K. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1996; 228: 662-668Crossref PubMed Scopus (193) Google Scholar, 29Ruest P.J. Roy S. Shi E.G. Mernaugh R.L. Hanks S.K. Cell Growth Differ. 2000; 11: 41-48PubMed Google Scholar). We previously found that the aggregation of the IgE receptor in RBL-2H3 cells induced the tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK, which was enhanced by cell adherence (23Hamawy M.M. Mergenhagen S. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 6851-6854Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To verify whether this FcεRI-induced tyrosine phosphorylation corresponds to FAK activation, we used phosphospecific antibodies, which selectively recognize the autophosphorylation and Src-phosphorylated sites on the FAK molecule. The culture of the RBL-2H3 cells as monolayers induced phosphorylation of Tyr397, Tyr577, and Tyr861 in quiescent cells (Fig. 2). Aggregation of the IgE receptor dramatically increased the phosphorylation of the residues Tyr397, Tyr407, Tyr577, and Tyr861. Therefore, in RBL-2H3 cells FAK was activated in resting cells, probably by cell adherence, and FcεRI activation led to an increase in FAK phosphorylation at the same sites that are known to be phosphorylated after integrin-induced activation. In 3B6 cells, a variant form of RBL-2H3 cells that is defective in IgE-induced secretion and expresses low levels of FAK, transfection of the wild type FAK, the kinase-inactive form of FAK (ATP-binding site mutated), or FAK mutated on the autophosphorylation site reconstituted the antigen-induced secretion, indicating that FAK plays a role as an adaptor molecule (25Hamawy M.M. Swieter M. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30498-30503Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). The COOH-terminal region of FAK seemed to be a good candidate for a potential role in the modulation of IgE-induced secretion, because it can bind a number of cytoskeletal and signaling molecules such as paxillin (9Schlaepfer D.D. Hunter T. Trends Cell Biol. 1998; 8: 151-157Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (436) Google Scholar). Furthermore, IgE aggregation induced the tyrosine phosphorylation of paxillin in RBL-2H3 cells (30Hamawy M.M. Swaim W.D. Minoguchi K. de Feijter A.W. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Immunol. 1994; 153: 4655-4662PubMed Google Scholar). To determine whether the COOH-terminal region of FAK regulated IgE-induced secretion, we transfected RBL-2H3 cells with FRNK, the FAK-related non-kinase, which corresponds to the COOH-terminal region of the FAK molecule (see Fig. 1). FRNK is expressed endogenously in fibroblasts (31Schaller M.D. Borgman C.A. Parsons J.T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 785-791Crossref PubMed Scopus (279) Google Scholar) and is an inhibitor of FAK function (32Richardson A. Parsons J.T. Nature. 1996; 380: 538-540Crossref PubMed Scopus (450) Google Scholar), probably by competing for the binding of FAK to cytoskeletal elements. Expression of FRNK in cells has been reported to decrease FAK tyrosine phosphorylation and FAK-dependent cellular functions, including cell adherence (4Maung K. Easty D.J. Hill S.P. Bennett D.C. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 6824-6828Crossref PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar), cell spreading (32Richardson A. Parsons J.T. Nature. 1996; 380: 538-540Crossref PubMed Scopus (450) Google Scholar), or migration (33Sieg D.J. Hauck C.R. Schlaepfer D.D. J. Cell Sci. 1999; 112: 2677-2691Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). By transfection FRNK was expressed in RBL-2H3 cell lines at levels that by immunoblotting appeared to be higher than endogenous FAK (Fig.3 A). The cell lines expressing FRNK were still adherent and grew as monolayers, but there was some decrease in cell spreading in several of the transfected cloned lines (data not shown). To further verify the functional effects of FRNK in RBL-2H3 cells, we tested the IgE-induced FAK tyrosine phosphorylation. FRNK transfection resulted in strong inhibition of the tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK and of the Tyr397autophosphorylation site in both resting and FcεRI-activated cells (Fig. 3 B). Although FRNK is phosphorylated on serine residues via a signaling pathway involving PKA activation in chicken embryo fibroblasts (34Richardson A. Shannon J.D. Adams R.B. Schaller M.D. Parsons T. Biochem. J. 1997; 324: 141-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar), it is unclear whether it can be tyrosine-phosphorylated. We next immunoprecipitated FRNK from resting and antigen-stimulated RBL-2H3 cells, and the immunoprecipitated proteins were analyzed by Western blot using anti-phosphotyrosine antibody. Surprisingly, FRNK was tyrosine-phosphorylated in resting cells (using a longer exposure of the film, data not shown), and FcεRI aggregation increased this phosphorylation (Fig.3 C). Because FRNK was tyrosine-phosphorylated and was effective in modulating FAK phosphorylation in these cells, we next examined IgE-induced secretion. After stimulation with optimal concentrations of antigen, the average histamine release in the 10 different cell lines transfected with FRNK was 41.2% ± 8% compared with 43% ± 4% in the parental cells (mean ± S.D.,n = 5), indicating that FRNK did not affect secretion. Therefore, although FRNK decreased the tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK, it did not modify the release of histamine. Previously we reported that transfection of full-length FAK in the secretion-deficient 3B6 cells, which express low levels of endogenous FAK, reconstitutes IgE-induced secretion (25Hamawy M.M. Swieter M. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30498-30503Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). In the present experiments we found that transfection of full-length FAK, which had an HA tag was also fully functional (Fig.4 A and see below). To further investigate the role of the COOH-terminal region of FAK in secretion, we stably transfected the COOH-terminal domain-deleted FAK (ΔC-FAK) in the 3B6 cells and clones expressing ΔC-FAK were analyzed for histamine release (Fig. 4 B, cell lines ΔC18 and ΔC20, and data not shown). The ΔC-FAK, like full-length FAK, still reconstituted IgE-induced secretion (Fig.5 A), indicating that the COOH-terminal region of FAK was not required for this function.Figure 5Histamine release from the parental 3B6 cells and 3B6 cell lines expressing the different truncated forms of FAK. A, cells were sensitized overnight with antigen-specific IgE and then stimulated with the indicated concentrations of the antigen dinitrophenol coupled to human serum albumin for 45 min. B, cells were stimulated with the indicated concentrations of the Ca2+ ionophore A23187. Histamine release is expressed as a percentage of total cellular histamine content. The results are the mean ± S.D. from five different cell lines tested for each variant form of FAK.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) The COOH-terminal domain of FAK contains the FAT sequence (focal adhesion targeting; see Fig. 1), which is thought to play a critical role in the cell-dependent activation of FAK (35Shen Y. Schaller M.D. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1999; 10: 2507-2518Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). We therefore examined the tyrosine phosphorylation of ΔC-FAK immunoprecipitated from resting and antigen-stimulated cells (Fig.4 C). The ΔC-FAK was tyrosine-phosphorylated in resting cells, and this phosphorylation was increased after antigen stimulation. When analyzed by phosphospecific FAK antibodies, the autophosphorylation site Tyr397 and the Tyr577tyrosine residue in the activation loop were phosphorylated in quiescent cells, and their level of phosphorylation was increased upon IgE receptor activation (although very slightly for Tyr577). These data suggest that ΔC-FAK is activated in resting cells, probably via cell adherence, and FcεRI aggregation augmented this activation. Although the FAT sequence may play a role for optimal FAK activation, it is not absolutely essential for the activation of FAK in mast cells. The kinase domain of non-receptor protein-tyrosine kinase (PTK) could play a role as an adaptor or linker molecule (36Zhang J. Kimura T. Siraganian R.P. J. Immunol. 1998; 161: 4366-4374PubMed Google Scholar). In 3B6 cells, the expression of the kinase-inactive variant form of full-length FAK (ATP-binding site mutated) reconstituted secretion (25Hamawy M.M. Swieter M. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30498-30503Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). However, this does not rule out the potential role of the kinase domain of FAK as an adaptor molecule in the regulation of mast cell secretion. To exclude this possibility, we expressed in 3B6 cells the NH2-terminal region of FAK (N-FAK), which lacks the kinase domain (see Fig. 1). Stable transfected clones were screened for the expression of N-FAK (Fig.6 A, clones N-11 and N-24, and data not shown), and several N-FAK positives clones were tested for histamine release. IgE-induced degranulation was still reconstituted in cell lines expressing N-FAK (Fig. 5 A). N-FAK was tyrosine-phosphorylated in resting cells, and FcεRI activation increased this phosphorylation (Fig. 6 B). These results suggest that (i) the presence of the kinase domain in the FAK molecule is not necessary to reconstitute secretion, (ii) the NH2-terminal region of FAK can reconstitute secretion, and (iii) N-FAK is still phosphorylated by other PTKs even in the absence of the autophosphorylation process. To definitively rule out a potential role of either the kinase domain or the COOH-terminal region of FAK in degranulation, the NH2-terminal-deleted FAK (ΔN-FAK, see Fig. 1) was transfected into the 3B6 cells, and several clones stably expressing N-FAK were tested for histamine release (Fig.7 A, clones ΔN-20 and ΔN-22). No significant increase in IgE-induced histamine release could be detected in the lines expressing ΔN-FAK, as compared with the parental 3B6 cells (Fig. 5 A). The ΔN-FAK was tyrosine-phosphorylated in resting cells, and this was slightly increased after IgE receptor aggregation (Fig. 7 B). The tyrosine phosphorylation of ΔN-FAK was in agreement with the observation that FRNK was tyrosine-phosphorylated in RBL-2H3 cells. However, these phosphorylations did not play any role in the degranulation process, because ΔN-FAK did not restore secretion. Altogether the degranulation experiments suggest that: (i) the kinase domain and COOH-terminal region of FAK are not involved in the modulation of secretion, and (ii) the NH2-terminal region is the critical element of the FAK molecule that is essential and sufficient for reconstituting secretion. In this report we examined which domain of FAK may regulate FcεRI-induced secretion in the RBL-2H3 mast cells. By using phosphospecific FAK antibodies, we found that receptor aggregation induced an increase in the phosphorylation on FAK at the same tyrosine residues that are known to be involved in its integrin-induced activation. The low level in the phosphorylation of the Tyr397 autophosphorylation site in resting cells was increased by antigen activation. Furthermore, in agreement with previous reports, which demonstrated that Src family kinases can bind to Tyr397 and then phosphorylate other tyrosine residues on FAK, the tyrosine phosphorylation of several other sites was increased by FcεRI aggregation, including Tyr577 in the activation loop, Tyr407 in the NH2 domain, and Tyr861 in the COOH-terminal region. However, the autophosphorylation site was not essential for FAK phosphorylation. Antigen activation of RBL-2H3 cells expressing FRNK, the COOH-terminal domain of FAK, led to the tyrosine phosphorylation of FRNK. Similarly, the NH2-terminal-deleted FAK expressed in 3B6 cells was also tyrosine-phosphorylated, indicating that tyrosine residues on the COOH-terminal region are still phosphorylated even in the absence of the autophosphorylation site. Nevertheless, the autophosphorylation site was necessary to get an optimal phosphorylation of the FAK molecule. For example, there was much less increase in the phosphorylation levels of Tyr577 and Tyr861 in ΔN-FAK expressed in 3B6 cells than in the endogenous full-length FAK molecule in RBL-2H3 cells (data not shown). These experiments also support our previous observation that autophosphorylation site-mutated FAK expressed in 3B6 cells is still tyrosine-phosphorylated after receptor aggregation (25Hamawy M.M. Swieter M. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30498-30503Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). Although these studies suggest that the tyrosine sites phosphorylated by adhesion and by receptor activation are similar, it is possible that there are other tyrosine residues in the COOH-terminal region (or the kinase domain) that are phosphorylated only following FcεRI aggregation. The COOH-terminal domain of FAK contains the focal adhesion targeting (FAT) sequence, which is critical for cell adhesion-dependent FAK tyrosine phosphorylation (35Shen Y. Schaller M.D. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1999; 10: 2507-2518Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar). Here, we observed that, in these mast cells, ΔC-FAK was tyrosine-phosphorylated in vivo and its phosphorylation level increased upon antigen stimulation. In agreement, expression of FRNK in RBL-2H3 cells inhibited partially, but not fully, the IgE-induced FAK tyrosine phosphorylation. These data suggest that the presence of the FAT sequence and the interaction of FAK with cytoskeletal elements are not absolutely critical for FAK tyrosine phosphorylation. However, such interactions probably are required for maximal tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK, because FRNK partially inhibited this phosphorylation. The COOH-terminal domain of FAK was not essential for reconstitution of secretion in the 3B6 cells. However, this domain of FAK has been found to be important in many cellular pathways. In various cell types, the COOH-terminal region of FAK is a key component for interaction with downstream signaling molecules such as adaptors and the activation of MAP kinases pathways (37Boudreau J. Jones P.L. Biochem. J. 1999; 339: 481-488Crossref PubMed Scopus (507) Google Scholar). This domain of FAK includes the FAT sequence, which is critical for cell adhesion-dependent FAK tyrosine phosphorylation, a proline-rich region that binds SH3-containing molecules and tyrosines that are phosphorylated and bind adaptor-containing molecules such as Grb2. Similarly, expression of FRNK in RBL-2H3 cells, which would have functioned as a competitive inhibitor, did not block histamine release. Therefore, these sites in the COOH-terminal region of FAK, although important for a number of signaling protein interactions, are not required for histamine release. The enzymatic activity of FAK and the kinase domain were not required for the reconstitution of histamine release in the 3B6 cells. We previously observed that the catalytic activity and the autophosphorylation site were not essential for the reconstitution of IgE-induced secretion by full-length FAK. However, because these two mutant forms of FAK were still strongly phosphorylated, FAK could still be activated and/or tyrosine-phosphorylated by another PTK, via a mechanism that would not involve the autophosphorylation site. In the present experiments, the results with the truncated forms of FAK clearly demonstrate that the reconstitution of optimal histamine release in 3B6 cells is totally dissociated from FAK activation. Indeed, we show that (i) FRNK inhibited FAK activation in RBL-2H3 cells but did not block histamine release, (ii) the expression of the NH2-terminal region of FAK in 3B6 cells reconstituted degranulation, and (iii) the COOH-terminal region and the kinase domain could not restore IgE-induced secretion. The NH2-terminal region was the critical domain for the reconstitution of histamine release in the 3B6 cells. This was apparent from the transfection with the different constructs; whereas the NH2 domain alone or together with the enzymatic domain reconstituted secretion, the ΔN-FAK construct, which included the enzymatic and the COOH-terminal regions, was ineffective. The two constructs N-FAK and ΔC-FAK were also tyrosine-phosphorylated in non-stimulated adherent cells, and this phosphorylation was increased after FcεRI aggregation. Thus, independent of FAK activation, some tyrosine residues present in the NH2-terminal region of FAK are still phosphorylated by other protein tyrosine kinases, which are activated by FcεRI stimulation. Furthermore, these phosphorylations occur even in the absence of the FAT sequence and the kinase activity. The mutated forms of FAK that reconstituted IgE-induced degranulation still contained the Tyr397 autophosphorylation site. However, it is unlikely that this Tyr397 site is involved in the modulation of secretion, because (i) the expression of full-length FAK with this site mutated still reconstituted secretion in 3B6 cells (25Hamawy M.M. Swieter M. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30498-30503Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) and (ii) the COOH-terminal region and the kinase domain, which are tyrosine-phosphorylated by Src family kinases that bind to this site, are not involved in IgE-induced secretion. The mechanism by which the NH2-terminal region of FAK regulates secretion is unclear. Indeed, this domain contains no known protein interaction sequences, and no signaling molecules have been reported that bind to the NH2-terminal part of FAK (if we exclude Tyr397). However, it is possible that this NH2-terminal region plays a role as an adaptor molecule, linking FAK to integrin and/or cytoskeletal changes that are involved in IgE-mediated secretion. The clustering of integrins is thought to lead to the binding of the NH2-terminal domain of FAK to the cytoplasmic tail of β integrins, resulting in FAK oligomerization and activation (9Schlaepfer D.D. Hunter T. Trends Cell Biol. 1998; 8: 151-157Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (436) Google Scholar, 15Schaller M.D. Otey C.A. Hildebrand J.D. Parsons J.T. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 130: 1181-1187Crossref PubMed Scopus (549) Google Scholar, 38Giancotti F.G. Ruoslahti E. Science. 1999; 285: 1028-1032Crossref PubMed Scopus (3757) Google Scholar). Therefore, it is possible that association of N-FAK with integrins could reinforce and stabilize the formation of stable complexes between integrins and other signaling molecules, resulting in enhanced FcεRI-induced secretion. These effects could be similar to the enhanced degranulation observed in adherent compared with non-adherent RBL-2H3 cells (24Hamawy M.M. Oliver C. Mergenhagen S.E. Siraganian R.P. J. Immunol. 1992; 149: 615-621PubMed Google Scholar). In conclusion, our results, together with those reported in the literature, support the idea that the NH2-terminal region of FAK could play a role in the modulation of in vivo cell functions by means of two different mechanisms. First, this region might have a regulatory role in FAK activation, thereby regulating cell spreading, migration, or apoptosis. Although the FAT sequence is the critical determinant for FAK activation in fibroblasts (35Shen Y. Schaller M.D. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1999; 10: 2507-2518Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar), it has been proposed that the NH2-terminal region blocks the phosphorylation of the autophosphorylation site. After β integrin activation, a change in the conformation of the NH2-terminal region of FAK would render the autophosphorylation tyrosine accessible for phosphorylation, leading to FAK activation (for review see Ref. 9Schlaepfer D.D. Hunter T. Trends Cell Biol. 1998; 8: 151-157Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (436) Google Scholar). Second, independent of FAK activation, the NH2-terminal region could itself act as an adaptor or linker molecule that can regulate other cellular events such as the IgE receptor-induced mast cell degranulation. We thank Drs. Juan Zhang and Maher Haddad for helpful discussion and review of the manuscript. We also gratefully thank Greta Bader for histamine analysis.
